results.description:
Large U-shaped array of produce vendors sells affordable (REALLY cheap!) produce

Open Fridays and Saturdays only.
After 4 pm on both days, the vendors "sell off" their produce for further discounted prices so they don't need to haul it back with them.

Highly recommended!!

Called either a "Farmer's Market" (but few if any farmers sell there) and "Truck Farm" (but no truckers sell out of their trucks; the vendors BUY discounted produce at Chelsea Market and sell it on Fridays and Saturdays from around 7 am to 6 pm

This is a host-free finder's meetup (no one will meet you at the Haymarket site; you go for the 'event' whenever you wish and enjoy what it can offer you).

results.description:
From the producers of the hit TV show Wipeout, WIPEOUTRUN lets us step into the soaking, sudsy running shoes of a game-show contestant. At Gillette Stadium on Saturday, August 1st, we can dash through an adventure peppered with oversized obstacles inspired by the program's original and official course, including slides slicked with soap suds, padded wrecking balls, and steep inflated slides. Once we conquer the gauntlet of swings and climbing walls, we'll zoom to the finish line down a four-story water slide. Then, it's time to celebrate with new friends at the all-day festival filled with food, refreshments, and souvenir booths.


https://youtu.be/gXiCbcmNaLI

Let's DO This!!!!

results.description:
The Jaycee walking club!
I am extending you this invite to get you moving!
We meet Saturday mornings, 7:45 am, Fruit Street Mansfield, WW II Veterans Memorial Trail (Bike Path). Just past the airport. We go for just about a 4 mile walk, takes a little over an hour, and we have lots of fun. If you can’t do the 4 miles come and do what you can and work your way up. We usually have enough people to split up into sub-groups of leisure walkers and speedsters.

I use Map My Walk to keep track of our time and distance. This is a free app that you can download to your smartphone, should you want to start keeping track of your exercise, minutes and calories burned. It has a lot of features that I am sure you would have fun with.

If you can, let me know if you will be walking with us, so we don’t start without you. If we are all gathered before 8 we tend to just get going at that point.

If you are interested in joining our walking club, either this time or sometime in the future, please let me know and I will include you on that email list.
Laureen House [masked]
results.name: Foxboro Jaycees Walking Club

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to two of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Osceola and East Osceola. We will use the the Mount Osceola Trail to first reach Osceola before continuing over to the viewless East Osceola. Along the way we will have to first descend, and then on the return ascend, the short but steep "chimney".

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

Group size will be limited to 12 people.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:


http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/24-Mt-Osceola-4340--34-East-Osceola-4156


Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 8.4 miles and climb about 3,200 feet. It should take an average hiker about 6 hours to complete. This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.53555&lat=44.00124#.VbVxPXjuh_Y


=== What to Bring ===


Use this link for a list of items needed for most three-season day hikes:

http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf 

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet Mount Osceola Trail parking lot that is located on the north side of Tripoli Road near Waterville Valley, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 130 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 9 minutes to drive there.

Here is a link to a customizable map: 

https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Boston,+MA/43.983534,-71.558708/@42.9814416,-71.7769824,9z/data=!4m8!4m7!1m5!1m1!1s0x89e3652d0d3d311b:0x787cbf240162e8a0!2m2!1d-71.0588801!2d42.3600825!1m0


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.name: NH4K ... Osceola and East Osceola (INTERMEDIATE)

results.description:
This is a cutback weekend! Full marathoners will do 8 miles and half marathoners 5 miles.  Note the change of location.

Parking: Please DO NOT park at the Kickstand Cafe parking lot.  There is a large, metered parking lot across the street. Or, you can also try to find spots without  meters a few blocks away from Arlington center. 

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc. 
Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-). 

Registration fees:  If you have not yet registered and paid the fees, please do so at this page.  http://www.teamaidasha.org/register Please contact us at [masked] if you have any questions.


Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html


About AID-Boston

Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at: www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT

Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at: http://www.ashanet.org/mit/

results.description:
This is the reoccurring meetup for the weekly open water swims at Walden Pond. A well attended venue for triathletes training for races of all distances.

The gate opens at 7 a.m. and the Parking is right off of Walden St. Walden charges to park a their lot ($5) via a computerized parking attendant that takes cards. I'd recommend the annual pass if you think you're going to come to more meetups. Alternatively, It's a short distance from Concord High School. Some people avoid the parking fee by parking near Concord High School and then walk/ride their bike over to Walden. Click here for the map of the parking.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Across and back from the beach (Pictured above) is a little over a mile mile; a perfect distance for those training for 70.3 and Ironman races.

There are also some close to shore routes for people getting better acquainted with open water (see distance maps). We meet near the lifeguard house right on the beach closes to Walden street. Here is the map of walden pond.

This meetup is important because you always want to swim in groups if you can. Make certain that you look out for each other. Don't attempt to swim across the pond if you haven't trained for that distance. Always match up with someone or a group that swims your pace. The beauty of Walden is that you can swim very close to shallow water and get some good open water training in.

If there are people that are looking to go long for the first time, let me know in advance and I may be able to swim angel, or get a swim angel group together. That way we can do it in a controlled and safe environment.

For those that are really new and nervous about open water swimming, stay tuned for a beginners clinic that I'll put on in the summer.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be by the Lifeguard house
results.name: Weekly Walden Open Water Swim

results.description:
Let's meet up next Saturday morning and shoot the "enthusiasts" waiting in line outside ComiCon. This is a fun bunch of people, all dressed to the nine's in some seriously intricate outfits, and almost all dying to have their photo taken. It's a "target rich environment" for portrait photographers into outdoor work and over the top people. If you have one, I'd recommend you bring an off camera flash to tame some of those shadows a bright morning sun can create. Maybe we'll get lucky and it will be cloudy!

Meetup is 1 hour before doors open. Let's meet at the second floor entrance to the World Trade Center, on the raised road that leads past the Partisans sculpture and towards BCEC. It's a pretty straightforward venue so we can probably guide late comers to the group or you can just head off on your own to photograph the costumed crowds.

This is a par 3 course so you can practice your short game.  The fee to join is $40 and it covers your handicap fee.  You can play 9 or 18 but have to decide which option when you sign up.

This league is flexible!

The website is www.middletongolf.com

There are leagues every day if Saturday does not fit your schedule.

venue.name: Church of the Good Shepherd

results.description:
• [Don't be concerned if you don't see many RSVPs here... our members tend to RSVP via our members site at WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org.]

Please arrive at 9:00 am. From 9 to 9:15 am, we set up the meeting and network. We start the meeting at 9:15 am, and continue until 10:45 am. When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left. If you arrive late, just walk in and have a seat at any open spot.

Please visit "Meeting Roles & Responsibilities" for more information about what to expect from a club meeting.

Here's a sample agenda for our meeting:

9:00 AM Setting up/Networking

9:15 AM President's Greeting and Club announcements

Welcome all to the First Watertown Saturday club.

Toastmaster's Welcome 

Introduces each role, its purpose, and the person who will perform the role.

Humorist/Invocation

Starts the meeting on a light-hearted note.

Grammarian's Word of the Day

Encourages each of us to add a new word to our vocabularies. Challenge us to use the new word spontaneously.

Scheduled Speeches


Club members give the speeches that they've scheduled and prepared in advance using the guidelines from one of the Toastmasters International communication manuals.

Table Topics

Our meeting's Topicsmaster provides our members and guests with an opportunity for demonstrating and honing their skills for impromptu speaking.

General Evaluator's Introduction


Introduces evaluation team members and evaluate the evaluators and the meeting in general.

Speech Evaluations


Club members provide helpful, supportive feedback to each of the scheduled speaker in a positive and friendly manner.

Grammarian's Report

Grammarian reports on how many times speakers used the Word of the Day and how we used the English language.

Ah-Counter's Report

Ah-counter reports how many filler-words and false starts were used by each participant, to raise speakers' awareness of these instances and to encourage improvement.

Timer's Report

Timer reports speaking times of all major speaking roles to encourage members learn to accomplish tasks within set time limits.

General Evaluator's Report

General evaluator provides a review of the meeting, what went well, and areas for improvement to encourage continual growth and an optimal quality of our meetings.

Toastmaster's Closing Remarks 

10:45 AM President Adjourns Meeting

We usually have a convivial lunch at The Red Lentil. Hang around after the meeting for details.

WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org
results.how_to_find_us: Park on Russell Avenue and enter Church of the Good Shepherd from Russell Ave. When you enter, walk downstairs and take a left.

results.description:
RSVPs are now closed. Looking forward to seeing everyone on Saturday!

UPDATE: Check your inbox for important event updates sent on 7/26. You can also find these updates on the Message Board.


ACTIVITY: We'll be making an art journal from scratch in the morning, then spending the rest of the day filling the pages (collage, painting, printing, stamping, lettering, embellishing, and more). All workshop materials supplied (although we'll ask you to bring a few things; watch for a message about a week in advance). A buffet lunch is included. Click here for more details.


VENUE: We'll be in an air-conditioned space on the campus of Lasell College in Newton, just about 1 mile from the junctions of Routes I-90 (the Pike) and Route I-95/128. Details will be sent to paid registrants.  


Early-Bird Price: $75. Payment in full was due by July 15. 

Last-Minute Price: $85. This is the fee for payments after July 15. If you are unable to RSVP, it means we are at capacity (22).   


Your fee covers:


• Your share of the cost for hall rental and set up


• Required insurance and taxes 

• Adjacent parking


• Buffet lunch (see Message Board for details; no one will go hungry)


• All needed supplies

• A welcome "goodie bag" and a collage packet 


• The chance to win auction items (see Pat's note about this below and on the Message Board)

• The chance to win a few door prizes


• A donation to the Meetup to help cover future costs.


If you can make an additional donation (suggested: 5-$10 donation), we'll put it toward a scholarship fund to help people attend Meetups, retreats, and other events. Every little bit helps. 


CHINESE AUCTION ADDED: We’ve decided to add a Chinese auction for anyone interested. This is a great opportunity to donate some extra art supplies, finished art pieces or other decorative items. Regifting is fine. Used tools and rubber stamps in good condition are fine, but not used ink pads, half used bottles of paint, etc. We’d like single items or groups of things with a value of $10+ dollars.  Click here for details.

TO SIGN UP: RSVP right here on this page. If you're unable to RSVP, reservations are closed, but you'll be added to a waiting list.


REFUND/CANCELLATION: Your deposit and payments are refundable, minus a $10 change fee, as long as someone takes your place. You may pay by PayPal (send to <a>[masked]--be</a> sure to use the "send money to family and friends option") or by check (email Anne for the mailing address).

- CycleMania is a good Rental Spot
- ride the Maine Narrow gague railroad to witness railway history
- Drive around Route 1 North to see some amazing sites

- Eat your favorite seafood (most likely gigangtic lobsters)
- Explore East End Beach (closer to the city)
- Explore Scarborough State Park (has a nice beach, further away from the city)
- Old Port
- Casco Bay 

OR

 MAKE YOUR OWN LIST!

Reach the Park: 6:30 PM

Head Back to the Boston, MA : ~8:30PM

Bring a light jacket, just in case.

results.description:
Let's meet for a Saturday Morning Beginner-Friendly & Advanced-Beginner Bike Ride Combo at Southfield in Weymouth!  We will be meeting and biking around the roads and off-roads of Southfield w/ members of the South Shore Hike Bike and Social Club (SSHBSC).  It's a great and relatively easy area to bike that we have returned this time for our 2nd Beginner-Friendly and Advanced-Beginner Bike Ride Combo.

 
We will bike 6-10 miles with a mix of mostly flat with some small hilly terrain in about 45-60 minutes. We will stop along the way every couple of miles or so. I do keep track of our mileage, time, etc. via an app on my phone.  (If you have an app to track as well please do so.)  Please bring your own bike.

 
Please Note:  

 1. Pace: As noted above, we will be biking 6-10miles in about 45-60 minutes so we will bike an average speed of 8-10 mph today. 
2. Please wear a helmet and review the rules of road. Please stay single file on the roads. Event Host/Organizer(s) are not responsible for any injuries or liabilities caused by participants.

3. This is weather-dependent. If the ground is too wet we will not bike.  I will post an update in the Conversations a few days prior to the event with a status update. 

**This event is being held in conjunction w/ South Shore Hike Bike & Social Club (SSHBSC).  If you are in both groups please note I can give you attendance credit in both groups [after the event] but you will need to RSVP Yes for SF and No for SSHBSC or Yes for SSHBSC and No for SF so I can easily find you in both groups as it's very challenging to find members in SF since it's so large.**

Optional: We can grab a late breakfast or an early lunch at a nearby restaurant afterwards or have a potluck picnic and/or plan some future South Shore Social Fun events.  

 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Biking Levels (Rough Guide):

~Beginner-Friendly: Approximately 5-8 miles of relatively flat terrain biking an average speed of 5-10mph in 45 minutes time.  All levels welcome.

~Advanced Beginner: Either approximately 8-15 miles of mostly flat terrains with some small hills OR approximately 4-6 miles of mostly hills.  (Great for training and getting the heart rate up.)  The flatter longer terrain will have average speeds of 6-12mph biking in about 45 minutes to an hour.  The hillier shorter terrain will have varying average speeds probably closer to 3-4mph uphill and 15+mph (yikes!) downhill averaging 4-12mph.  Both will take about 45 minutes to 1 hr and 15 minutes.  All levels upward welcome.  (Beginner-Friendly bikers may be able to join us on some of these rides. Please check w/ the Event Host(s)/Organizer(s) before signing up to join this type of event.)

~Intermediate: Ride length of 12-25 miles with varying degrees of flat and hilly terrains.  We'll be biking about 8-15mph in about 1-1.5hours.

~Advanced: You can bike 20+ miles in about 1& 1/2-2 hours at an average speed of 12-20mph.

~Expert: You can do it all!!  This is a rare group of talented individuals.

***As always, safety first!  Please wear a helmet and review the rules of road.  Event Host/Organizer(s) are not responsible for any injuries or liabilities caused by participants.  Bike Rides are weather-dependent. If the ground is too wet we will not bike.  I will post an update in the Conversations a few days prior to the event with a status update.***

results.description:
Let's meet for a Saturday Morning Beginner-Friendly & Advanced-Beginner Bike Ride Combo at Southfield in Weymouth!  We will be meeting and biking around the roads and off-roads of Southfield w/ members of the South Shore Hike Bike and Social Club (SSHBSC).  It's a great and relatively easy area to bike that we have returned this time for our 2nd Beginner-Friendly and Advanced-Beginner Bike Ride Combo.

 
We will bike 6-10 miles with a mix of mostly flat with some small hilly terrain in about 45-60 minutes. We will stop along the way every couple of miles or so. I do keep track of our mileage, time, etc. via an app on my phone.  (If you have an app to track as well please do so.)  Please bring your own bike.

 
Please Note:  

 1. Pace: As noted above, we will be biking 6-10miles in about 45-60 minutes so we will bike an average speed of 8-10 mph today. 
2. Please wear a helmet and review the rules of road. Please stay single file on the roads. Event Host/Organizer(s) are not responsible for any injuries or liabilities caused by participants.

3. This is weather-dependent. If the ground is too wet we will not bike.  I will post an update in the Conversations a few days prior to the event with a status update. 

**This event is being held in conjunction w/ South Shore Hike Bike & Social Club (SSHBSC).  If you are in both groups please note I can give you attendance credit in both groups [after the event] but you will need to RSVP Yes for SF and No for SSHBSC or Yes for SSHBSC and No for SF so I can easily find you in both groups as it's very challenging to find members in SF since it's so large.**

Optional: We can grab a late breakfast or an early lunch at a nearby restaurant afterwards or have a potluck picnic and/or plan some future South Shore Social Fun events.  

 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Biking Levels (Rough Guide):

~Beginner-Friendly: Approximately 5-8 miles of relatively flat terrain biking an average speed of 5-10mph in 45 minutes time.  All levels welcome.

~Advanced Beginner: Either approximately 8-15 miles of mostly flat terrains with some small hills OR approximately 4-6 miles of mostly hills.  (Great for training and getting the heart rate up.)  The flatter longer terrain will have average speeds of 6-12mph biking in about 45 minutes to an hour.  The hillier shorter terrain will have varying average speeds probably closer to 3-4mph uphill and 15+mph (yikes!) downhill averaging 4-12mph.  Both will take about 45 minutes to 1 hr and 15 minutes.  All levels upward welcome.  (Beginner-Friendly bikers may be able to join us on some of these rides. Please check w/ the Event Host(s)/Organizer(s) before signing up to join this type of event.)

~Intermediate: Ride length of 12-25 miles with varying degrees of flat and hilly terrains.  We'll be biking about 8-15mph in about 1-1.5hours.

~Advanced: You can bike 20+ miles in about 1& 1/2-2 hours at an average speed of 12-20mph.

~Expert: You can do it all!!  This is a rare group of talented individuals.

***As always, safety first!  Please wear a helmet and review the rules of road.  Event Host/Organizer(s) are not responsible for any injuries or liabilities caused by participants. Bike Rides are weather-dependent. If the ground is too wet we will not bike.  I will post an update in the Conversations a few days prior to the event with a status update.***

results.description:
FIRST SATURDAY SPEAK UP


If weeknights are difficult, take advantage of this Saturday meetup to build confident speaking skills. [We'll be meeting First Saturdays unless a holiday (like Labor Day) moves us to the preceding weekend]. Our Meetups are fast-paced and entertaining. Not intimidating. You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meetups run. [This session will supplement our usual Wed evening meeting, not replace it. Sessions start promptly, so please arrive a bit early.]  Please rsvp.

3rd Floor, Room 097. You must take the elevator by the security desk to access the floor.

Parking: If you can't find street parking, there is parking to the rear of the bldg. You will present your ticket to the security desk on your way out ($3), then insert the ticket at the gate as you exit.
(Don't park in the supermarket/Porter Square shopping center parking lot.)


See the "About Us" tab for more info.


NOTE: For those who like to plan far in advance, our next Saturday session will be a "Last Saturday" (Aug 29) due to Labor Day weekend.

FREE

We'll work outdoors, helping with weeding, watering, harvesting, and other tasks. No experience required, and training, tools, and gloves will be available on-site.

From live music, historical re-enactors, and tall ships, to interactive programs and crafts for families, all events and activities are free and open to the public. Let's spend a couple of hours at the festival and then grab a sandwich or an ice cream at Pickering Wharf.  Wear comfortable shoes and sunblock.

results.description:
Let's ride the swan boats and have a picnic lunch in the beautiful Boston Public Gardens. We can then go to a nearby vendor cart for a freshly-squeezed (and maybe overpriced!) lemonade, or ice cream.

Plenty to see and do on the Boston Common as well! Here's a description from their website:


"True to its origins, the Public Garden is a botanical showcase both for those who admire its beauty and for those who value it for information.
The first public botanical garden in America, its form, plantings, and statuary evoke its Victorian heritage. This green and flowering oasis in the heart of a great metropolis has become a Boston icon. No visit would be complete without a stroll in the Garden and a voyage on one of its Swan Boats."


Some exceptional, not-to-miss features in the Boston Public Garden include the flower beds, tropical displays, tulips, roses and over 600 trees including the famous elms, willows and beeches.

We can meet at Oak Grove at 10:00 am on the Melrose/Malden line, and take the Orange line to Downtown crossing and walk the block to the Common, stroll through the Boston Common taking in the sights and sounds, and then head for the Public Garden and Swan Boats.  Others may choose to meet in Boston, say at 11:00 am at the Park St. Station, or another locale.

Subway: ~ $6.00 round trip (with Charley Card, a bit less)
Swan Boat ride: $2.75 for adults
$2.00 for seniors
Ice Cream or lemonade: ~$5.00
Bring your own lunch
Some may opt to bring a treat or cookies to share, but it's not necessary.


We can bring small blankets to sit on or find benches, bring lunch in insulated lunch bags and have an ice cream or other such summer treat.

Can stay and shop in nearby Downtown Crossing afterwards.  Let's hope for good weather.  Rain cancels the event.
results.name: Swan Boats & Picnic In Boston Public Garden, Sat. Aug 1

This 3 hour workshop will take you through designing and building your very own 3D printed bracelet, necklace, or key chain. You'll learn how to make a 3D model using 3D CAD, and how to use a 3D printer to make your designs.

IF YOU HAVE YOUR OWN COMPUTER PLEASE BRING IT. HATCH only has SIX laptops available for use, first come, first served!

results.name: Intro to 3D Design and Printing

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the triangle between Magnolia and Thorndike Fields, just off the bike path.
results.name: (Arlington) - Intermediate Swordplay, Dagger and Grappling

results.description:
CodeCombat is a step above Scratch but below a full-blown introduction to Python / JavaScript. It’s a web game (codecombat.com) where you move a character around using basic instructions to move and fight. Instead of Scratch blocks, you type commands (in JavaScript or Python) and learn basic concepts like variables and loops. You get quick feedback but now typing is required.

This is our first time doing CodeCombat and we're testing it to see if it's a good intermediate step between Scratch and the more challenging classes including the Minecraft modding class coming again in October. 

Prerequisite: Must have attended the CodeCombat session on Sat July 25th. The second session will build on concepts learned in week 1. 

Location: We’ll be at the LogMeIn office in the Fort Point Channel area of Boston. The address is 320 Summer Street, Boston 02210. Map: https://goo.gl/maps/vMvDj. There should be street parking (bring quarters for the meters). The nearest T stop is South Station.

What to bring: Please be sure to bring a laptop (not a tablet) and charger. If you need a laptop, please let us know by emailing [masked]. 

RSVP Instructions: If you could please RSVP only for the number of kids attending, it would be helpful for us in calculating our numbers. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1". If you can't make it, please update your RSVP so that someone from the waitlist can take the spot.

Interested in Mentoring? We're always looking for mentors. If you're proficient in Python, Javascript (or another programming language or coding tool) and are interested in volunteering, please let us know.

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who decide to join get a $10 deduction from membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

results.description:
The Israelite nation was developing its own identity and culture, but they were on the brink of destruction. The people wanted to find respect and recognition on the world stage, to feel secure and powerful, and to be prosperous and comfortable in their own homes.  But this was at a time when everyone was doing what was right in their own eyes.  Doesn't sound so different from today, does it?  But God wants to show us a better way--a man who will do all his will, a king after God's own heart.

Join us as we investigate the story of 1 Samuel and the different lessons for us!

We've been in need of a little more adventure and exploration, so let's check out the Boston Harbor Islands! We'll catch the ferry to Georges Island at noon, spend an hour or an hour and a half touring the fort, before hopping back on the ferry and continuing to Peddocks Island for a real hike. The last ferry leaves Peddocks at 5pm, and will take us directly back to Boston by 5:45. (There are also ferries leaving earlier if you can't invest an entire afternoon.)

Pack snacks/lunch and bring a water bottle, and enjoy another side of Boston!

The Boston Harbor Cruises Ferry Center is located on the north side of the Marriott Long Wharf Hotel. I'll be there by 11:40am. The ferry leaves at noon, so if you miss it, you miss it! So don't be late.
http://www.bostonharborcruises.com/harbor-islands/

RSVP: Please RSVP if you plan to come. If you RSVP, I'll be waiting outside to hear from you, so please show up, or let me know if circumstances change! If you ditch us without warning more than once, we'll have to remove you from the group. When you RSVP, you're making a commitment and taking a spot, so come. If you need to get a hold of me, my number is four four zero 488-5055.

results.description:
Social In Boston Presents:

BOSTON ROOF DECKS TOUR

The Summer of 2015 is going to be a great one for the members of Social In Boston! One part of what makes it so great is our weekly roof deck tour. Each and every Saturday we'll be visiting a different roof deck for food, drinks, relaxation, and socializing. Please the details carefully every week, as the details are going to change. Some venues have better times to visit than others, and as already stated, each week will be in a different location...

Our Eighth Stop…

Finally, the last stop on the roof deck tour is upon us.…

Situated near the corner of Beacon Street and Chestnut Hill Ave in the Cleveland Circle neighborhood of Brighton, MA sits this quaint little place. If you are familiar with this area at all, then you know that this is a pretty busy intersection most of the time, with people driving through to the Boston College area, passing through to Chestnut Hill, or just heading east onto Beacon Street into the Brookline neighborhood. Yes, this place is near the old Cleveland Circle Theatre — in fact, right diagonally across from it. For those of you located a bit further out of the city, Cleveland Circle’s CitySide Bar is a great roof deck for grabbing a burger and a beer and watching the game on their many TVs.

Check out the food menu and the drinks menu.

Join us on the roof deck to eat lunch, relax, and savor an experience like no other! : )

GETTING THERE

CitySide is at 1960 Beacon Street, Brighton, 02135.

Click here for directions on Google. Take the C Train on the Green Line to Cleveland Circle.

Street parking is possible but it can be tough, and there is some parking near the restaurant. Try your luck if you come early.

See you there Socialites!

~Matt

results.description:
(a set of 4 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is four linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all four classes (July 11, 18, 25, and Aug 1) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)

results.description:
Organizer: Joe Ciarcia -[masked]

***** PLANS HAVE CHANGED *****
>>>MEETING TIME HAS CHANGED TO 3 PM<<<
We will meet at the Old Bridal Path parking lot as originally planned. I estimate we'll be off the trail sometime between 10 PM and 11 PM.

=========================

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself or others at risk so consider this before you decide to participate.

=========================

***** NEW SIGNUP PROCEDURE *****
If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months. (similar in this case means similar difficulty in terms of distance and elevation, prior night hiking experience is not required)

What We're Doing...

What are we doing? Simply one of the best hikes in the world and we're going to aim to be on the summit of Liberty a little before sunset (8:08 PM), and then enjoy the rest of the ridge via full moon (moonrise is at 8:48 PM... by the time we hit the alpine zone again, the moon should be up). Note: we will not hit the OBP parking lot until around 2 AM to 3 AM, possibly later. Keep this in mind. Also, be on time! We will not wait for stragglers as this hike's start time is very time critical.


Use this link for more information about the summits and trails:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/6-Mt-Lafayette-5260--7-Mt-Lincoln-5089

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/18-Mt-Liberty-4459--25-Mt-Flume-4328

Guests are not permitted.


Dogs are permitted - Dogs must have a flashing LED collar for this hike. be sure to bring a leash in case you need to use it and a copy of their current rabies vaccination.

Trip Summary...

Distance: 14.5 miles
Vertical: 5,693 feet.
Book Time: 10 hours and 6 minutes

The point of this trip is to enjoy a time of day when we're usually not up on top of a summit. As such, I expect the completion time for this hike to be longer than book time as we'll probably linger on the summits a littler longer, however, when we are moving we will be moving at a faster than book time pace (moving average in the 1.7 to 2 MPH range (book time pace for this hike without rests would be 1.4ish MPH).

This event is considered to be ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain. We could alter our plans because of fatigue, weather, and/or other conditions - there is no guarantee we will complete the entire event as described here.

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

You need to become self-reliant by learning about the route and potential hazards since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety.

What to Bring...


EVERYONE MUST BE CARRYING TWO HEADLAMPS WITH FRESH BATTERIES (and yes I will be checking). One of those headlamps must be LED based. Don't forget the layers as well as it's likely to be colder than your standard day hike.


Use this link for a list of items needed for a three season day hike (exception to list, NO COTTON):

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf


Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

Weather...

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.

Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.16074668800047&lon=-71.64432606299965&site=all&smap=1#.U3esRMeMFGE

Directions...


We will meet at the Old Bridal Path Trailhead to spot cars which is located off of Rt. 93 after exit 34A (do not get off at exit 34A). According to Google Maps this meeting spot is 137 miles from Boston and it should take about 2 hours and 7 minutes to drive there. Since this is where we will finish the hike will leave a few cars there and drive to the spot were we will start the hike. 

Use this link for customizable driving directions:

• <a>https://www.google.com/maps/dir//44.142066,-71.681358/@44.1424003,-71.7500904,12z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m3!4m2!1m0!1m0</a>;


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride. If you do share a ride be sure to share the expenses (gas and tolls).

Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer...

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
Explore how to use Color, Composition, and Creativity to take better photos. It may be true that beauty is in the eye of the beholder, but there are some fundamental design principles that can help you see with the eye of an artist.

When you travel you tend to see the world with a fresh eye. We will experiment with ways to apply this mindset to what we can photograph right here in Boston.

During this workshop I will reveal 3 design principles that can make your photos more visually interesting, compelling and powerful. For example we will look at how to use asymmetrical composition to create visual balance as illustrated in the photo below. 

Photo by participant Suzanne K in Chinatown

We will start in Chinatown at the Gate and do a series of short fun assignments to help you see where to stand to get the best angle on the shot and how to simplify the scene so it is interesting but not chaotic. You need to always be clear about what is the subject of the photo before you click the shutter. In this image taken by a former student, the subject is the man making the move on the game board. Everything else is organized around him.  Leaving the red sign in the upper left corner gives us vital information about the context of the image.

Photo by participant Dianne Ward in Chinatown

In this fun and educational event, you'll discover  techniques that improve every single photo you take from now on. Bring your iPhone, Point and Shoot or DSLR. All levels welcome to participate in this workshop.

• How to be confident about where to place the subject for the greatest impact.

• How to use aperture or shutter priority to make sure your photos are in focus and properly exposed.

• How to use basic design principles to add visual interest and creativity to your photos.

• How to be more comfortable photographing people on the street. 


 The techniques you learn in this workshop can easily be transferred to your next travel adventure.

Photo by participant Lisa Watchmaker

Then join us and discover how to capture the true beauty of a place. Discover how to see the hidden structure of the scene. Once you see it, you can capture it in your photos. You will immediately feel the difference in your photography because they will have more impact and power. 

This is a "no technical jargon zone", so if you're a total beginner, I promise that you will feel at ease and totally comfortable in this relaxed and fun setting. I provide individual coaching and suggestions so you will improve immediately. 

Tuition for the class is $30.00. We will stay and get a bite to eat after class if you want to join us for the social part of the class. We always have a great time and look at the photos during the social time. I hope you can join us on Saturday for some summer fun!

If we cancel due to weather I will issue a refund right away.

Suzanne

results.description:
The 3rd  restaurant in our 2015 North End dining series will be at Benevento's

If you want a North End restaurant that serves ample portions of authentic Italian food with freshly made pasta, hand-tossed brick oven pizza loaded with toppings, and offers a classic, casual North End Italian atmosphere with professional service, then Benevento's is for you. Benevento's looks like an authentic Italian restaurant, acts like an authentic Italian restaurant, and creates meals that taste like authentic Italian food. What more could one want when seeking a hearty Italian meal in the North End of Boston? (Please bring cash)

http://beneventosboston.com/

After dinner for those that would like to we can head over to Hanover Street and enjoy the feast of St. Agrippina.

And, of course our North End dining series would not be complete without having coffee and dessert at Caffe Vittoria for a cup of espresso, cappuccino, specialty coffee drink and a cannoli, teramasu or lobster tail. Time to meet at Caffe Vittoria will be made after dinner. (Please bring cash) 

On the way back to the train station you may want to take a walk along the Rose Kennedy Greenway and enjoy this new piece of art.

Suspended high above one of the Greenway parks, the mostly orange form looks unreal from a distance, like the flare on a camera lens. Get closer, and you see the huge nets swelling and rising with the breeze. Its colors grow vivid in the sunlight, fading when it’s cloudy. It is soft and organic in a canyon of hard-edged glass and stone. Spend a little time with it, and you see more. It doesn’t just alter the space, and the sky above, but also the people who take it in. Like all great art, it is transporting. It also reflects the kind of courageous, free-spirited vision for the city that many have been longing for forever.

For those interested in taking the train we will be meeting at the Oak Grove Train Station at 4:15 pm.

The North End dining series is very popular.  Please when you RSVP be sure you are planning on attending.  RSVPs changed after 12:00 pm on Friday, July 31st will be counted as a no show.

results.description:
Saturday Night Sit is a community meditation practice group, peer facilitated and free to all. Group sittings are held Saturday nights from 6:30pm to 7:45pm at Karma Yoga Studio on Newbury St. in Boston, MA above Trident Cafe. We meditate together to explore and expand upon our meditation practice. Sits begin with a guided meditation, followed by a short talk and group discussion. Donations accepted to cover space rental.

No meditation experience, religious affiliation, or anything else required...All you need to do is show up.

All are welcome.

https://www.facebook.com/groups/saturdaynightsit

Join us for Providence's August Lock and Key Singles Party! A great non-intimidating way to meet singles in the Providence metro area!

Lock and Key Events are the new, interactive and FUN way to network, meet your match, make new friends....or just to have a great time!

Details of our next Meetup:

August 1st, 2015

http://i215.photobucket.com/albums/cc205/Darwood66/PRIZE%20SPONSORS/ScreenShot192.jpg?t=1327394482

The Whiskey Republic
15 Bridge Street
Providence, RI 02903
(Note: They recently changed the name of the street from South Water Street
to BRIDGE ST., so, unless you have updated your GPS System,
it will probably not show up)

Suggested Age range: 24-49 (if you are a little older or younger...no biggie!!)

Check-in: 6:30 - 7:00 PM
Mix and Mingle: 7:00 - 9:00 PM
Prize drawing at 9:00 PM
Done at 9:15 PM and then stay and party until closing with no cover!!

INCLUDES:
- Drink Specials during the event!,
- FREE APPETIZERS (until 8:00 PM),
- Great prizes, and the opportunity to massively mix, mingle, make new friends, and more!!


How It Works
 Every woman gets a padlock. Every man gets a key. Your goal is to match the right key with the right padlock. Every time you unlock you get a ticket that enters you into the drawing to win great prizes from our party sponsors. Prizes such as cold hard cash, hotel stays, dinners, tickets to popular things to do and more. After every unlock you get another lock or key so you can get back into the fray and meet more people!

For information on how to attend at the special MEETUP price call or email Sandy at (401)[masked]or [masked] or call or email Customer Service toll-free at (877)[masked] or [masked]!!

Use the code BOSMEETUP to attend for ONLY $19 - OUR MEET-UP MEMBERS PAY A MUCH LOWER PRICE TO ATTEND THESE SUPER FUN EVENTS THAN ANYONE ELSE. Or, you can pay $25 CASH at the door IF you put in an RSVP. Otherwise, it's $30 at the door!!

PRIZES YOU CAN WIN!
Every time you unlock, you can win prizes such as:

One $50 CASH Prize! One $50 Gift Card at The Whiskey Republic One - Gift Certificate for a Shampoo, Cut and Conditioning Treatment from Kimberly Lombardi: Hair/Color Specialist ($50 value) One - In Office One Hour Professional Zoom Tooth Whitening and Consultation from

Please email or call me with any questions!!

See you there~
Sandy
(401)[masked] or call (877)[masked]

results.description:
https://www.facebook.com/events/926613214053081/

The Spiritual Art of Chinese Calligraphy and Tai-Chi

Soulful words in lovely, spirit-filled Chinese characters can inspire insight and add willpower in your daily life. Dr. Sung, a native of Taiwan, is offering an interesting and informative workshop in Cambridge for anyone who loves art and holistic works. Dr. Sung has a unique professional background in the field of education. Please see details below. In the first 30 minute of the workshop, Dr. Sung will lead participants to practice basic Tai-chi movements, with focus on breathing and energy balance within individual and individuals with environment (moving meditation). After reaching the calming status, Dr. Sung will lead participants to practice calligraphy of either ancient hieroglyphs or modern regular script styles (kai-shu). Individual instructions based on participants’ different levels will be provided.

In addition, participants are encouraged to bring to the workshop their favorite words in English and discover their meaning in Chinese characters. Practice writing them on paper and select the best effort as your artwork of the day. You will love the single-stroke touch and be amazed by its power and meaning for your heart and your health. Come learn this unique method of self-empowerment and healing in this creative and dynamic class. This workshop is appropriate for anyone age 10 and above. - RSVP PLEASE –
Participants who signed up by noon, Thursday, July 30 will receive a hand written Chinese calligraphy. Dr. Sung will select a word or a phrase specifically for the participant (based on his observation and understanding of participant’s specific characteristics) and write the word or phrase on a paper in the front the participant. This individualized and thoughtful calligraphy is the participant’s to keep.


Date: Saturday, August 1st, 2015
Time: 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM


Fee: Free. An optional donation of $5 or more is suggested


This event is sponsored by YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION INC. (www.Yuan3Chih4Edu.org), a not-for-profit organization promoting global educational and health care resources sharing, and Tomoko’s Wednesday Dinner. All donations go to YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION, INC. to promote continuous community educational and health care services.


Location: Central Sq., Cambridge, MA


*8 minute walk from Central Square Red Line T station
*Bus # 1, CT1, 47, 64, 68, 70, 70A, 83, and 91
Parking: On-street parking on Broadway (meter enforced till 6 pm, please check current regulation; Green St. garage for more than 2 hours. What to bring: comfortable clothes, and your choice of art paper or sketchpad, and brushes, if you have them. *Traditional calligraphy paper, ink, ink sticks, stone stand, and brushes will be provided if needed.


Contact: [masked]


Dr. Yung-Chi Sung M.A., Ph.D.


Born in Taipei, Taiwan, Yung-Chi grew up in a family of teachers. His parents were both teachers. His father taught physics and his mother taught Chinese literature. This may explain how and why he developed a mind that simultaneously admired arts and appreciated the sciences.


Dr. Sung has a B.S. in Psychology from Soochow University in Taipei, , an M.A. in Linguistics (with a minor in Cognitive Science), an M.A. in Educational Psychology (with a minor in Psychology), and a Ph.D. in Educational Psychology (with a concentration in Psychological Foundation, Learning, and Cognition, and a minor in Cognitive Science, Linguistics, Neuroscience, and Psychology). He was a research assistant at the Department of Psychology, National University, Taipei, Taiwan. In 1997 he went to University for graduate studies and was a research assistant and method/statistics consultant at University of Minnesota Medical School from 1998 to 2005. Within that period of time, he also served as the President and on the Board of Directors, was Chair of Education and Community Development Committee, Chair of Finance Operation Committee, and Chair of Policy Committee for Chateau Student Housing Cooperative, a not-for-profit co-op providing affordable housing for students from diverse backgrounds, including US and international students.


He served as Assistant Director of Outcomes Assessment at University of Maryland University College (UMUC) at Adelphi, Maryland from 2005 to 2008, where for one year he also taught Tai-Chi for stress relief as a diversity initiative. From 2008 to 2014, he was the Director of Evaluation and Assessment at the Tufts University School of Medicine, and Assistant Professor in the Department of Medicine. In 2015, he accepted the position as Director of Assessment and Institutional Effectiveness at Northwestern Health Sciences University, a university aspiring to be a world-class health sciences university, that educates students, practitioners, and leaders in health and wellness solutions to help people live healthier lives.


Yung-Chi is a long-term devoted educator. He has been an Adjunct Assistant Professor at UMUC since 2006, and was promoted to Adjunct Associate Professor in 2015. He is also an Associate Professor at NWHSU. He is currently developing a not-for-profit organization (YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION) to promote global sharing of educational and health care resources. In his spare time he enjoys reading, writing, dreaming, dancing (recently salsa and argentine tango), and occasionally playing poker (currently no-limit Texas Hold’em).

results.description:
ADVANCED TICKETS  - PLEASE purchase tickets ahead of time as this WILL sell out.

SPECIAL APPEARANCE

Boston, MA, Kendall Square Cinema
Saturday, August 1 for a Q&A after the 7:00pm show and to introduce the 9:45pm show: Director Joshua Oppenheimer and executive producer Errol Morris


The Look of Silence is Joshua Oppenheimer’s powerful companion piece to his Oscar-nominated The Act of Killing. Through Oppenheimer’s footage of perpetrators of the 1965 Indonesian genocide, a family of survivors discovers how their son was murdered, as well as the identities of the killers. The documentary focuses on the youngest son, an optometrist named Adi, who decides to break the suffocating spell of submission and terror by doing something unimaginable in a society where the murderers remain in power—he confronts the men who killed his brother and, while testing their eyesight, asks them to accept responsibility for their actions. This unprecedented film initiates and bears witness to the collapse of fifty years of silence. Winner of over a dozen international awards, including the Grand Jury Prize at the Venice Film Festival and Audience Award for Festival Favorite at the SXSW Film Festival.


The Look of Silence is Joshua Oppenheimer’s powerful companion piece to his Oscar-nominated The Act of Killing.

Director Joshua Oppenheimer and executive producer Errol Morris will be present for a Q&A after the 7:00 showing.

Simply not to be missed, 

John

results.description:
Learn to dance salsa @ Havana in Cambridge (Beginners Welcomed). 300 dancers +

A meetup event brought to you by Boston Latin Dancers, a subsidiary of Boston Meetup Group. 

Join us - and 300+ dancers 
9-10 pm Salsa Lessons. Beginners welcomed!  
(Beginner and Intermediate Lessons)

10 pm to 2 am - Salsa dance party. 

Look for a table that says Boston Meetup Group and for Erin K, the organizer. I can be reached at (978) 395-7020.

9-10 pm Salsa Lessons.

10 pm-2 am Salsa Dance Party

21+. $12 (Admission includes lesson and party)

Dress Code: Smart Casual to Elegant

(No ball caps, no work boots, etc.) 
Beer, Wine, Mixed Drinks, etc. available at Bar 
No partner required 
Beginners very welcome 
No need to pre-register 
Music format: 65% salsa, 25% bachata, 
10% merengue/cha-cha-cha

I love the midnight dance performances! You do not want to miss those.

 
Havana Night Salsa is Boston's biggest salsa dance party featuring salsa dancing and lessons with Salsa y Control, an amazing venue filled with 300+ welcoming salsa dancers, an inexpensive parking garage next door, and public transport on Mass Ave. (Red Line, Buses 1, 64 etc.) one block away! 

288 Green St, Central Sq, Cambridge

Have your party with Havana Club! Birthday? Graduation? Wedding? Outing w/ co-workers? This is the best place to celebrate. 


Driving Directions: Take Storrow or Memorial Drive to River St. (where the two gas stations are), then a right on Mass Ave, a right on Pearl St (where FootLocker and Putnam Furniture is), and your first right on Green St. 

Parking: There is a large, inexpensive ($1.50/hr, $6/night maximum) parking garage right next door - you can't miss it!

Walking Directions (from Red Line's Central Stop): From Mass Ave take a left on Prospect St then a left on Green St. It is a one minute walk. 

Please note that the Friday Night Salsa parties are 21+.
results.how_to_find_us: Call or text Erin K, the organizer, at (978) 395-7020 if you have any questions

results.description:
” Embrace light. Admire it. Love it. But above all, know light. Know it for all you are worth, and you will know the key to photography.” – George Eastman 

There are two times of day with special qualities of light that make our photos shine. Early morning light and dusk. For this shoot we will get up early, get out there and capture the beautiful early morning light along the Charles River. The colors are more saturated, the shadows deeper, and the wildlife more accessible. 

Yes it is harder to get out there early in the morning but if you want to really take some outstanding photos, you need to make the extra effort. Bring your coffee, your camera and your desire to catch the light. I guarantee it will be worthwhile. 

Some of the topics we will cover:


• What are the best camera settings for proper exposure?  I will help you take your camera off the auto setting so you have more control over the results.

• How to capture the more subtle qualities of light to express a mood.

• How to work with reflected light, shadows, and silhouettes. 

Bring your questions and I will provide individual coaching.

I love to photograph light and can't wait to share what I have discovered during the past 20 years with you. The skills you learn during the workshop can be applied to any subject: people, nature, architecture, flowers, and landscapes.

I believe in the photographer's magic — the ability to stir the soul with light and shape and colour. Amyn Nasser

Tuition for this workshop is $30.00 and class size will be limited to 15. I hope you will set your alarm, get up early and join us! All camera types are welcome and all skill levels. I always present the material in  a way that is accessible to everyone. Yes there will be handouts so you can repeat the assignments on your own to hone your skills. 

Suzanne
results.how_to_find_us: We will be by the Hatch Shell refreshment stand at the base of the Arthur Fielder Foot Bridge

Send texts to my Google Voice number:[masked]


A long time ago in a park far, far away… this group had an annual picnic. On one day each year we did not fear the daystar. We braved the outdoors, we embraced nature, and we absorbed UV rays. Then came the dark times, the inside times… but no more! The Boston Sci-fi/Fantasy Meetup Group Annual Summer Picnic RETURNS!

I am going to shamelessly steal from the last picnic, way back in 2012, for this one.


Meet at:
Brewer Fountain next to the Park St. Subway entrance from 10:00 to 10:30 AM. At 10:30 we will venture forth to find a large area to picnic. For a map: https://goo.gl/WSvppM


Things to Bring:


• Blankets

• Lawn chairs


• Outdoor games (but maybe leave the lawn darts at home)

• Board games (ones with many tiny pieces may not be a good choice)

• Food (this is not a catered event, but we hope you’ll bring extra goodies to share.)

• Cold drinks

• Picnic Supplies

• Bug Spray

Children are welcome

Things you should not bring:


• Pets (website says “have or allow any animal, except a dog on a leash no longer than eight feet, or cat under proper control; or walk a dog in a designated Dog Free Zone.” So use your discretion there, and they can’t be taken into the Public Gardens.)

• Alcoholic Beverages (I hate to be a buzzkill, but it isn't legal in the Common.)

• Fireworks

• Weapons

• Anything else that could get you or other members of the group arrested

Anything really valuable that you would be heartbroken to have stolen/eaten/destroyed/rained on

Weather Note
Picnics in the rain are no fun. We'll watch the weather and if it looks like it will be a rainy day, we'll reschedule, so stay tuned.
results.name: Summer Picnic Outing

results.description:
Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿

results.description:
Were restarting the session curriculum, so if you haven't come before heres a perfect first session!! Those who have been in attendance will be put on an advanced track for the session.

This week we work on safety in landings, and precision jumping!

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 

This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be on the main courtyard up the stairs. The location itself is of concrete construction, and has yellow rails!
results.name: [Boston] Parkour 101 - Introduction to Parkour // Safety + Precisons

We're Going To The Beach!

There's nothing like a day at the beach, so let's all meet at the most convenient one in the Boston area, Revere Beach! To make this Meetup extra special, we're going on the last day of the Revere Beach National Sand Sculpting Festival!

https://youtu.be/2_tS462Wl2c

PERSONAL MUST-HAVE CHECKLIST:

- Bathing suit
- Towels
- Sub block or tan lotion
- Sunglasses
- Sandals
- Small cooler
- Bottled water
- Packed lunch
- Change of clothes

VOLUNTEERS NEEDED TO BRING:
- Beach balls
- Volley ball and net
- Football
- Big coolers full of ice
- 12 packs of sodas
- Bags of pretzels, chips, etc..
- Umbrellas! 
- … 
- … 
- …

What else do we need?? Leave your comments below.

Volunteers:

If anyone can and will volunteer to bring the above mentioned items, please contact me ASAP so we can work out the details. ~Matt

GETTING THERE


Taking The T: Take the Blue Line out to the Wonderland stop, it's the last stop. Walk across the foot bridge and look for the crowd with blankets on the beach, just beyond the big clock and down the stairs.

Driving: Click here for the <a>Google map</a> to get your directions. There is plenty of free parking around the beach area, click here for the Google map for parking. There will also be cheap parking close to where we are for about $5. At least that's what it was last year.

More details to come. See you there!

~Matt

results.description:
Come join us at our regular Scrabble Meetup, and play over lunch or a pastry and some coffee!

We meet twice a month, every month, on the first and third Sunday. Please bring a board if you have one. We have a few spares, so you are welcome to come even if you forget your board.

Newcomers are always welcome. We keep 2 and 3 letter "cheat sheets" for new folks to keep the playing field more even.

We mostly play Scrabble one-on-one, and pairing is random. If you would like to be matched up to someone of a similar skill, just let the organizer know.

Au Bon Pain is right next to the Davis Square T stop, and there is typically ample free street parking on Sundays.  A few times a year, there is a race in Davis Square that shuts down some streets, so keep an eye out for that. If possible I will send out a message to the group the day before.

$1/Meetup goes to help pay for the annual Meetup.com dues and miscellaneous photocopying, but if you are a regular $10/year will be easier for you and me to keep track of!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the people with Scrabble boards out--the cafe is usually empty on Sundays.
results.name: Twice-Monthly Scrabble Meetup (First Sunday of the Month)

results.description:
Come and join us for open board gaming at Excelsior!  They have a large gaming area to seat approximately 50 gamers in addition to a growing board game library that patrons may take right off the library shelf and play at-will.  They have also dedicated their Sunday schedule for just this open board gaming event, so us board gamers will have the pick of the tables during the entirety of the event which happens to run the entire time the shop is open on Sundays.

Attendees are welcome to bring in their own games or use games from the library.  Bobby will also run game demos during the event in case you want to learn a new game or simply try before you buy.

In case you are interested in purchasing the game from the demo session, Excelsior will offer 10% off the price of purchasing a new copy of that game that day on top of the 10% discount they are offer to all MBG members (for a total discount of 20% off).  If for some reason they are out of stock of the demo game and must special order it for you that day, they will order it for you and allow you to take an additional 10% special order discount on top of the previous two discounts for a total discount of 30% off!

Want to special order something that is not the demo game?  Add the base TGA 10% discount and the 10% special order discount together for a total of 20% off any special orders.

Nourishment:  The shop carries various snacks and non-alcoholic beverages if you need something to snack or sip on while you game.  For more substantial food, there are many eateries located within walking distance from the shop on Main Street.

Parking:  Excelsior has an agreement in place with the Jiffy Lube at 3 Powder Mill Road.  Attendees may park in the lot behind the Jiffy Lube building.  From there, it is a short walk across Powder Mill Road to the Excelsior's door on the corner of Powder Mill and Waltham Street, which is the 4-way intersection closest to Jiffy Lube.
results.how_to_find_us: On the corner of Waltham Street and Powder Mill Road, park behind the Jiffy Lube

results.description:
This is the new, regular meetup on Sundays at noon at Brooklyn Boulders in Somerville.  Please note that Seth will be taking over hosting this event this week.  Meet by first table/bench thing by the entrance.

(Credit to Francesco Cardiello for the information below):
BKBS is the gorgeous, new, state-of-the-art climbing gym most convenient to those in the Boston, Cambridge, and Somerville area. Although pricier, it features 60+ feet toproping and lead climbing, a massive 22 x 140 foot bouldering wall (and there's still another upstairs), yoga & fitness classes, a sauna, awesome water fountains that fill your water bottle, a retail store, lounge area, weight room, and a soon to open cafe! There's even a collaborative work space where you can study, work, and climb!
If you are looking for a partner or just want to get your climb on join us on Wednesdays for a fun time.

FAQ:

How do I get there? BKBS is conveniently located within a 10 minute walk of the Porter Square station. Walk down Somerville Avenue and turn right on Properzi way and head all the way down. It is also very bike accessible. If you drive, you can find the lot at 30 Dane St. It is located next to Artisans Asylum.

Why should I do this meetup? Since BKBS is such a new community (opened in late July 2013) few people have developed regular climbing partners to train and climb with. This is a great opportunity to meet other climbers interested in BKBS. Climbing is an inherently social sport - to top rope and do lead, you need to meet people who are dedicated to climbing. The Wednesday meetup assures you'll meet a partner to regularly climb with. We are looking to expand to other nights in the future.

What if I haven't climbed before? First off, don't be intimidated. Everyone started somewhere. If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the Learn the Ropes class. More info can be found here: http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before using the walls. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need? You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time? Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): Day Pass - $22 (Students $18)
10 Pack - $200 (Students $169)

RENTALS: Shoes - $5
Harness - $5
Chalk Bag - $2
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Sunday

results.description:
From the website:

"DeCordova is internationally recognized as a major venue for the exhibition and interpretation of modern and contemporary outdoor sculpture. The Sculpture Park occupies the entire campus: 30 acres of beautifully landscaped lawns, forests, fields, gardens, and terraces on a rolling site along the shore of Flint’s Pond in Lincoln, Massachusetts."

It is a beautiful space with lawns for running (and tiring those kids out!), trees for climbing, sculptures that you can interact with, and much more! It is also a great place for a picnic if you want to arrive early.

Adult admission is $14, but kids 12 and under are free! I also recommend checking with your local library, as they frequently have passes that will get adults in for $5.

This is a great place that is both fun and educational. Hope to see you there!

http://www.decordova.org/

http://www.decordova.org/sites/default/files/1/11_DEC_02Oct_064.jpg?1329253048
results.name: Let's run around at the deCordova Sculpture Park!

Our group has moved to Boston Red Dog Pet Resort & Spa.

Red Dog has a beautiful playroom with rubber floors, chairs, restrooms (for humans) and tons of exclusive space for our pugs to run and play.  We will be changing the Meetup to 1 hour as the cost to rent the room has increased to $45 an hour plus tax.  We will consider new venues for our Meetup but for now we will only be doing one hour.  I will be collecting a fee from each pug family on the day of the Meetup of $5 per dog for the first two dogs and $1 for each additional (for those of us that have a handful of pugs).  The facility is very clean and well managed and they require all pugs attending the Meetups to have veterinary proof of Rabies & Distemper vaccinations. You will not be able to participate in the Meetup without these records from your vet.  Please have your records with you for EACH Meetup.

Boston Red Dog also offers our members a $5 off coupon to use in their store Skipton Pet Center on the day of the meetup!

Check out our new home!  http://www.bostonreddog.com/


Thanks everyone and we look forward to seeing you!!

results.description:
Gena Bean will be having a lively discussion with Christopher Raiche, hosted by the Humanist Hub in Harvard Square as part of their Sunday series.

Discussion topics will probably include what it means to have a direct experience of that which inspires you in your life. There will be experiential exercises for the participants. 

Gena Bean is the founder and director of MindfulBoston.com. Since 2004, she has taught stress reduction techniques through lecture, class and retreat, in service to hundreds of individuals and numerous organizations. Her personable teaching style is grounded in experiences from her own meditation practice that began in the mid-1980s. 

Christopher Raiche (MDiv '17) is the Humanist Hub's Values in Action intern. He has over 20 years of meditation experience. He has taken on many roles in his life, including but not limited to: meditation teacher, Buddhist monk, and musician.
