Continuing on the freedom trail, we will sketch in the node of historic locations near King's Chapel. Nearby, there is the not-as-old City Hall, a famous statue of Benny Frank (below), and a couple of notable graveyards. It should be hectic with tourists and the weather forecast is promising sun! 

The tombstones have great little details, and the church is very square and symmetrical until you get into the fussy cornices and capitals! 

Similar contrast as last week between the old and new buildings as well.

We will convene near the entrance to the graveyard adjacent to King's Chapel at 2pm, disperse to sketch, and reconvene to share near the graveyard at 4pm.

Hope to see you there!

(Technical Support: <a>[masked]</a>)


The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru

At this year's Lammas Circle, we will flow into the energy of Yemaya, the Ocean Goddess, attuning with her rhythms and finding our own. As we walk the beach and breathe in the fresh salt air, we will open ourselves up to relax, release, and reconnect.

Come at 4:00 to swim and walk the beach, and to gather found objects to co-create our altar. At 5:00 we will circle up for our ritual time, which will include breathing, guided meditation, chanting, drumming, and walking by the edge of the ocean. We will end by blessing and sharing a ritual loaf of Lammas bread before our potluck feast.

This year, we will be meeting at a slightly different area of the beach, close to one of the bathhouses. You'll find us near Pavilions 1 and 2, between Beach Street and Shirley Avenue, and directly opposite the Revere Beach T stop. Parking may be available on Revere Beach Boulevard, or you may need to circle around to the parallel street, which is Ocean Avenue.

Please RVSP to [masked] so that we know how many women to expect. We'll meet rain or shine. If it's raining, we'll be in Pavilion 1 or 2. If the weather is good, we’ll be on the beach, just behind one of those two pavilions.

Please bring:
-swimsuit and towel if you wish to swim, sun hat, sun screen
-beach chair and/or blanket
-water shoes
-rattles, drums, and bells
-$ donation ($15 donation, or less for low-income)
-potluck food in a cooler
-your own tableware, cloth napkin, and water to drink

GPS
For GPS directions, use 82 Revere Beach Boulevard, which is closest address to corner of Shirley Ave. Public Transportation
1. Take the Blue Line to Revere Beach Station
2. Cross the street and head straight to the beach.
3. Look for us near Pavilions 1 and 2 For more information and to RSVP, contact Nouri at [masked]

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE: Tavern in the Square in Porter Square

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Look down the street. There's Tavern in the Square! If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Erika and Jack
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
{The Insight Masters class has just concluded. A few local graduates have agreed to share their big ah-ha's, on a panel as well as via presentations, with us.}


Our Topic This Evening Will ....

..Allow you to share the big Ah-Ha experiences that graduates received from their three+ month journey in the Insight Master's class. 

Boston was selected to be the first place on the globe to host The Insight Masters Class, the first major new seminar extension of Insight Seminars in two decades.  45 people, many of whom were quite senior personal growth leaders, attended from around the world, and, lucky for us, some of them are local PGN members.

I have asked local graduates to make up a panel to share their big lessons from this impressive training and answer your questions about how they incorporated their lessons into their lives.  A few have even created a personal presentation of their learning.  

There will be plenty of concepts offered here that you will want to consider perhaps investigating for your life.

We will have at least two independent presentations by the leaders.

- Returning to Inner Peace
- Handling Triggers


To prepare ....

1) What triggers you in your everyday life?  
2) How do you return to inner peace in your everyday life? 
3) Who has qualities that you wish you could emulate?
4) What holds you back most from living the life of your dreams?

Our Leaders This Evening

Antoinette Riley, a long time volunteer and Head Sound with Insight and the leader of the Pure joy Team.

Brad Rogers, a recent Insight Grad and volunteer who has embraced the Insight work with dynamic results in his life.

Matthew Winston, a long time leader and volunteer in the Insight community.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/

venue.name: Highland Park

results.description:
The annual FREE Jazz at the Fort concert is always a wonderful community event.

Berklee College of Music and the City of Boston Parks and Recreation Department's ParkARTS program present Jazz at the Fort. Along with the wonderful music, artists will have their work on display.

The Bill Pierce Collective will present a swinging jazz set built around saxophone and organ.


Pierce is chair of Berklee’s Woodwinds Department and a 1972 Berklee College of Music graduate who has appeared with artists such as Marvin Gaye and Stevie Wonder. In 1980, he joined Art Blakey’s Jazz Messengers, serving as music director and sharing the bandstand with other talented musicians such as Donald Harrison, Wynton and Branford Marsalis, and Bobby Watson.

After three years of recording and touring with Blakey, Pierce joined Berklee’s Woodwind Department while remaining active in both Boston and New York scenes and regularly performing with the Freddie Hubbard Quintet. In 1985, Pierce joined the Tony Williams Quintet. He made five recordings with Williams and toured Europe, Asia, and America. He has also recorded several albums under his own name for the Sunnyside label. Since 1999, Bill has been a member of the Kevin Eubanks Quartet, which has released five recordings. In addition to his many performances and recordings, Pierce is an internationally recognized music educator who has presented clinics in Europe, Asia, and South America as well as throughout the United States.

Entry ways to Highland Park are on Fort Avenue or Beech Glen Street in Roxbury. The park is wheelchair-accessible. Parking is available at Columbus Avenue and Cedar Street in the Roxbury Community College lot.

The park is a short walk from the MBTA Orange Line Roxbury Crossing Subway Station.

In the event of rain, the concert will move to the nearby Roxbury Community College's Media Arts Center, 1234 Columbus Avenue.

For more information visit berklee.edu/events or call[masked]<a></a><a></a>.

Get there when you can and stay as long as you're able.

Suggest you bring:

1) chair or blanket

2) snacks or supper

3) insect repellent

4) board games/playing cards

results.description:
This event is a combination of a Match Live event and Speed Dating.  Join other fun and friendly singles for a casual and comfortable singles party that you won't want to miss.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

$15 ADMISSION INCLUDES:

*Light Appetizers

*Ice Breaker

*Amex Gift Cards for Ice Breaker Winners

*Supplies/Name Tags

PRE-PAY HERE: http://mixnmatchboston.eventbrite.com

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Here is how it works..

-Upon arrive you will be given a name tag with your code name and number..

-You will also be given a sheet where you can keep track of everyone you meet.

-We will have an ice breaker games throughout the night where you will have a chance to meet others at the event and write down the code names and numbers of those you wish to make a connection with.

-At the end of the night write down the names and the numbers of the people that you met and would like to see again.  You will then hand in your sheet and we will send you the contact info for all the people who have a mutual match with you! You will be able to choose up to 10 people for potential matches.

The Night Will Feature:

Ice Breaker game with prizes -Full menu is available (pay as you go)  -Music played at conversational levels

Can I come alone? Yes 98% of those attending will be coming on their own. 

 What are the age ranges? This event will cater mostly to 30's-early 50's.

results.description:
From 6:30 to 7:30 PM, every Sunday evening, the BK Learning Center for Peace is open to everyone wanting to deepen their meditation experiences, filling the self with peace and power to develop spiritual capacity for the challenging week ahead.

Guidance and simple visual exercises that enable us to access our inner peace and strength will be offered during the meditation session.

 

All are welcome to attend and no RSVP is needed.

 

This is offered FREE OF CHARGE as a community service
results.name: Sunday Night Meditation

results.description:
For the 180th consecutive Sunday, we will be walking.   Let's join 20 or so others from other walking groups for this walk.

The walk is on, rain or shine.

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.


Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

We'll all go out for dinner afterwards, somewhere in the neighborhood.
results.name: Large,Multigroup Weekly Walk around Fresh Pond,dinner @ Shangri-La :8/2@6:30

results.description:
This event is a combination of a Match Live event and Speed Dating.  Join other fun and friendly singles for a casual and comfortable singles party that you won't want to miss.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

$15 ADMISSION INCLUDES:

*Light Appetizers

*Ice Breaker

*Amex Gift Cards for Ice Breaker Winners

*Supplies/Name Tags

PRE-PAY HERE: http://mixnmatchboston.eventbrite.com

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Here is how it works..

-Upon arrive you will be given a name tag with your code name and number..

-You will also be given a sheet where you can keep track of everyone you meet.

-We will have an ice breaker games throughout the night where you will have a chance to meet others at the event and write down the code names and numbers of those you wish to make a connection with.

-At the end of the night write down the names and the numbers of the people that you met and would like to see again.  You will then hand in your sheet and we will send you the contact info for all the people who have a mutual match with you! You will be able to choose up to 10 people for potential matches.

The Night Will Feature:

Ice Breaker game with prizes -Full menu is available (pay as you go)  -Music played at conversational levels

Can I come alone? Yes 98% of those attending will be coming on their own. 

 What are the age ranges? This event will cater mostly to 30's's-early 50's's.

results.description:
Let's join 20+ walkers and some other walking groups for:

Over 2 years of reliable walking

Please note that this walk does not start at the same place as the other Fresh Pond walk.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.

"Commonwealth Shakespeare Company's annual free Shakespeare on the Common production will be King Lear, to be performed July 22 — August 9, 2015 outdoors at the Parkman Bandstand on Boston Common, in partnership with the City of Boston and Mayor Walsh. The program, which has become a beloved civic institution, will draw an estimated 75,000 people over 16 performances.

Bring a blanket or low folding chair, perhaps a picnic basket, and get ready to enjoy a magical evening of free theater under the stars.

Lawn chairs are available for rent in the chair rental tents on either side of the stage. Chair rentals are $5, plus a $5 deposit that will be returned to you when you return the chair."

results.description:
Meet at the head of the trail in Bedford. This is across the street from Bikeway Source, which is why I listed it. We'll meet in the parking lot by the trail, not by the store! I put there store there for your GPS. We'll bike down to Davis Sq., have lunch or snacks as each person wishes, and then bike back.

Feel free to pack your lunch or to buy it, whichever you prefer. Some folks may want to take an hour stop, some just 20 -30 min. Either is ok. It's a personal decision, but that also means the group might split. There is an opportunity to stop in Arlington at the Kickstand Cafe. on Mass Ave and Swan Pl. (by Rt. 16).

Wearing a Bike Helmet is mandatory. If you don't have one, don't sign up or come. Bringing water, gatorade, V8, etc. is also mandatory. You will need it. Pls. let me know what your pace generally is. I will not be making us stick together, but it is nice to know what to expect before we start out. My own pace averages 11 - 12.5 mph.

If the weather appears to be iffy, I will check the morning of the ride and make a decision then. Often, the weather will be predicted to be bad, but will clear the morning of the ride. Please check for messages that morning if you are concerned.

I attest and verify that I (and any guest(s) I bring are physically fit to participate in any portion of each event I attend. I grant Metrowest Retirees Ready for Adventure Group permission to use any photographs, film or videotapes of all events for any purpose. AS A CONDITION OF ATTENDING THIS MEETUP, YOU AGREE TO: Hold harmless, and indemnify the organizers and their relations and heirs, and all members and participants of the Meetup group from any and all claims for injury, illness, death, and/or property damage including those caused by negligence, ignorance, inexperience and other reasons. You also agree to assume all mental, physical, financial, and/or other risk associated with this meetup. Kayaking, camping, hiking, bicycling, and other activities pose inherent risks and dangers. Participation in these activities is voluntary and dependent upon your own personal judgment. As organizers we make no claims regarding any expertise for this outing. This is not a guided tour. In the interest of safety, consuming alcohol before or during any Metrowest Retirees Ready for Adventure Group event is not allowed. *IE: We're all in this together. No "leader", just exploring and having fun together! Now, let the fun begin!*

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Summer is finally here and, for the Society of Professional Consultants, that means gearing up for our annual barbecue and panel discussion. This August, we plan to go back to a topic that we’ve done before, but that always captures attention: tech toys.

One of the challenges that consultants and solo professionals face is the need to be their own IT departments. It can be hard enough to keep up with necessary hardware and software updates for the technology you’re already using. It can be even harder to keep an eye peeled for the next new thing.

But SPC is here to help. Our panel, moderated by Steve Balzac, the Society’s immediate past president, will include Bob Goodearl of RGood Software Inc., and Rick Pollak, The Presentation Medic, as well as other tech gurus. They will present a selection of new (or maybe new-to-you) devices, accessories, programs, and apps that can help you work more efficiently, and make work more fun.

We expect this session to be even more interactive than usual. If you’ve got a favorite gadget or program that’s made a big difference in your work life, come prepared to share.

So pack up your kit and join us! Dress for this event will be casual, and weather permitting, we’ll be outdoors. The cost is $50 for members and first time attendees. All others are $55. Late registration for members is $60 and $65 for all others.

Please remember to pay for the meeting online at http://www.spconsultants.org/event-1821158 or bring a cash or check to the event.
results.name: Tech Toys:  Making you more efficient & work more fun

Synopsis:

Meryl Streep takes on a whole new gig – a hard-rocking singer/guitarist – for Oscar®-winning director Jonathan Demme and Academy Award®-winning screenwriter Diablo Cody in Ricki and the Flash. In an original and electrifying film loaded with live musical performances, Streep stars as Ricki Rendazzo, a guitar heroine who made a world of mistakes as she followed her dreams of rock-and-roll stardom. Returning home, Ricki gets a shot at redemption and a chance to make things right as she faces the music with her family. Streep stars opposite her real-life daughter Mamie Gummer; Rick Springfield, portraying a Flash member in love with Ricki; Kevin Kline as Ricki’s ex-husband; and Audra McDonald as Kline’s new wife.

https://youtu.be/x8PVK6Hky2A

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who have purchased the $10 intro pack get a $10 deduction from $110 membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: </a>Parking: <a href="http://www.fortpointpier.com/info.php#DirectionsParkingPortage">Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest MBTA stop is South Station on the Red Line.

results.description:
Fitness doesn’t need to be intimidating or extreme, but it does need to produce good RESULTS! Come join TFW Boston for an after-work happy hour… errr I mean workout. 

Our workouts make will make you BETTER, not just tired, and our fitness familia will help you enjoy your time and ENCOURAGE you to give your best!

What to expect: 

• A challenging, motivating and downright fun environment for training - perfect for after a long work day. 

• Experience the Training For Warriors ‘Hurricane’ workout as seen on ESPN, The New York Times, and Boston Fitness Magazine, and has created world champions in multiple professional sports


• Effective warm-ups to ensure all participants perform optimally and remain injury-free. 

• Sweat, smiles, and lots of high-fives. 

What NOT to expect: 

• Bootcamp instructors barking in your face. 

• Workouts that put exhaustion before results and safety.


• Participants that are there just to feel like they’re better than someone else.

If you want to lose fat or build muscle, build strength, improve confidence and overall health, this is the place to be. Please bring water, workout clothes and shoes, a hand to high-five with, and a friend(if you’d like)
results.name: Outdoor Workout in Dewey Square!

results.description:
Bucket List: Dream Big and Live Bold

A BUCKET LIST is a number of experiences or achievements that a person hopes to have or accomplish during their lifetime (oxforddictionaries.com).

A Bucket List is also called Wish List, Dream List, Priority List, My List… Let’s not wait to start doing.....

Your LIST should inspire you to dream BIG, live BOLD and be Present and motivated. Let’s the list be your guide you to everything you dream of, every wild adventure.

• “Well behaved women rarely make history”

This meet up is for optimistic, encouraging and friendly women; who would lend and get support from each other that will make the list easier to achieve, and encourage each other to tick as much as they can in their list.

At our first meeting we shared the experiences we already had, the things we crossed off our lists. 

During this meeting we will be adding to and sharing our lists.  Please bring your list with you.

No perfumes please we have members with allergies.

There is no charge for this event, however to use there room it is a requirement that EVERYONE that attends order food, I can't stress this enough, the restaurant is in business to make $$ and provide a service.  We are free to use their party room at no charge if we purchase food.  Please be respectful to this request.

results.description:
WE ARE BACK AT TUFTS FOR TONIGHT, PLEASE TAKE NOTE OF THIS.

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
New:

Due to time constraints and the game being very adjustable to new players joining and leaving at any time, I am making a change.

I do wish people to get something to compensate IHOP for letting us use the space, however, if you have not started or finished eating by 7:15pm please, start or finish eating at another table. The rest of the people will clean the table and start playing.  I want the rest of the players to have a chance to finish a game.


The rules give new players the opportunity to join the game at the start of any new hand, with the score of the mean player.

I am trying to keep the game and conversation balanced for everyone.  If multiple players are eating, conversing and playing,  the game may be held up until some people are restless.

Also, the more people eating and playing while handling the cards, the greater chance the few decks of "Jumbo Index" cards used for Negation Hearts will be marked and hard to shuffle, detracting from the game.

As always, please put your cold drinks on a napkin.

Thank you;

Negation Hearts Night. New players are VERY welcome: We will teach you how to play.

It is suggested that you get a drink or something else there, to compensate the hosting establishment. .

PUBLIC:

Both: The 450 and 456 Buses have nearby stops. 

Negation Hearts is played with two decks of cards. Two of the same cards like two king of clubs negate and the next highest card of the suit lead takes the cards played. So, even playing a two has not been safe at times. The scoring and passing are slightly altered from "Cancellation" hearts so that new people can join in or leave at the start of any hand.

The 50 cent charge is totally voluntary and is only to approximately cover the meetup charge.

This is SOCIAL CARDS conversation is encouraged, however please be aware of when it is your turn to play a card, we try to keep the fun balanced between the two.
results.name: Negation Hearts in Salem @ IHOP *

results.description:
The meeting will focus on grassroots activism.  While educating ourselves on issues and philosophy is very important, the Greater Boston Tea Party's original and ongoing objective is to get out there and make an impact, whether that means calling a representative, writing a letter to the editor, working on a campaign / running for office, or as small as correcting your liberal friend on the facts surrounding an issue.

Most recently, we helped avoid a major fiscal nightmare by making Mayor Marty Walsh back down on the 2024 Olympics in Boston. Despite Marty vehemently denying it - those "10 people" really can make a difference!

There are many other ways to get involved as well. We will be discussing current and upcoming issues, events, and how to get involved. We are also looking for members to share  their own stories and ideas.  

We will be making some announcements about several exciting events. There are at three (and potentially more) nationally known speakers this fall. Plus there are several areas of activism coming up where we need to be involved.


We can turn back the tide of creeping government intrusion into our lives - come join us to discuss how!

----------------------------------------------

Traditional Boston Meeting notes:

We will again have a social hour at 6:30 pm and have the meeting begin at 7:30 pm.

Parking – from Parkopedia. It appears the Dalton Street garage is the best value, with a flat rate of $15 in the evening. Note the green lines denote on-street parking. You need to go to a meter pay station to get slip for your car – pay up to 8 pm.

Parkopedia:  http://en.parkopedia.com/parking/bar/lir-ma/

NOTE: As always with Boston parking, things are subject to change. Special events will cause parking lots to hike their prices, and we do not check in advance to see if there are any such occurrences coming up.
results.name: Boston Meeting - Greater Boston Tea Party

results.description:
Indoor Rock Gym:  Central Rock Gym Watertown Ma (Monday's)

This Meetup is for weekly climbing at the Central Rock Gym in Watertown, MA. This meetup is intended to provide climbing partners for both lead and top rope climbers that sign up for the meetups.

Meet by the cubbies facing the Lead Wall (they will be on the right as you enter). I (Lovey) am usually wearing a teal harness with green & black climbing shoes.  Climb for 1.5 to 3 hrs. Adults of all skill levels and ages welcomed.  

**If you are leading, you should have your own rope. Work it out with your partner as to whose rope you'll be using if only one rope will be used between the two of you. Sometimes lead climbers prefer to lead on their own rope so both lead climbers may bring their own ropes to use. Word of caution: other climbers may help themselves to the second rope when it's not in use.


**If you come late, come find me or ask the CRG staff for help.  They know we climb on Mondays and can help you find the group. 

**There is another meetup group (and perhaps a second) that also climbs Watertown Mondays nights. If you miss the RSVP deadline, would appreciate a courtesy email/call to let me know you'll be joining us so I know to expect you.


**You are required to fill out the rock gym waivers. Go to their website http://www.centralrockgym.com/watertown.php and fill out their Liability Waiver online to save time when you arrive at the gym. 

**It is your responsibility to make sure you have taken the CRG Belay and/or Lead tests. If you have never climbed at CRG, you will be required to take their Belay test given by their staff only. Please make certain to come a bit early to allow for time to take their belay test.

**If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the "Intro Belay Class". You can sign up for this class (http://www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown under "Climbing Instruction).

**If you are interested in taking their Intro To Leading Climbing class, you can sign up for it at (http://www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown under "Climbing Instruction).

Equipment required: harness, shoes, chalk and belay device. 


Day Passes - $20 (Student/Military: $16)

10-Day Punch card $180 (Student/Military: $144)


Gear Rental:

- $8 Full Package

- $5 Harness

- $5 Shoes

- $2 Chalk

- $2 Belay Device

Membership options and further details are available on the website:http://www.centralrockgym.com/watertown.php

=============================================

Waiver:  Read !!!

Be Warned!

Mountaineering, Skiing – Alpine or Back Country, Rock & Ice Climbing by its very nature is an extremely hazardous activity.

Falling off any part of an climbing route or bouldering challenge or other associated activities, even hiking to a destination may result in injury or death. Weather, Trail conditions be it a slip on a trail or falling objects like rocks, climbing gear or tree’s from above, or avalanche can all incur injuries and/or death. 

Any information on this Meetup group page is for the basic understanding of what could be encountered. We do not guarantee any type of accuracy on this information. Seek your own additional resources of information.  You as an active member! Perhaps, lacking any of the following: professional training, good judgment, moral character or a conscience. We or anyone on any Meetup-Mountaineers cannot be held responsible in anyway.

When arriving at any Meetup you should always use your own best judgment. You must decide whether or not the conditions “ both physical or mental” are in your best interests. 

You cannot blame the organizer(s) if you get hurt. To join this meetup event you must acknowledge that you have read this waiver and thereby you completely and totally agree to indemnify the organizer(s) from any possible legal action related to any type of illness, injury, loss of equipment etc. that might potentially occur. We are not guides or leaders in any event held. Just the organizers of finding a meeting location that people with similar interests can meet and socialize.

That said have fun! Play safely! And take the responsibility of your own actions.


The Organizers…

results.description:
Welcome to our regular meetup!  We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing board games -- specifically, the kind of board games that make you think.  We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.


This season, in addition to playing games, we will be raffling off a bunch of popular games!  There will be a raffle at each meetup.  Simply by showing up, you'll get a chance to win free games. The more often you come, the more entries you'll receive.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message ahead of time, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm until the last people leave (usually quite a few hours).

Our group has been running since 2007, and at this point we have a pretty large crowd of regulars.  A lot of people come once every few weeks, and RSVPs are appreciated but not required, so the RSVP list is often smaller than our actual attendance.  We expect about 30-45 people at most of our meetups.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

People new to Euros are very welcome.  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); the heaviest strategy games (like 18xx or wargames); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan and Carcassonne.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (You will also receive extra raffle tickets any time you donate.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block away from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza.  We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot).  When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).
results.name: Boston Shorinji Kempo Open Dojo Event

results.description:
Sometimes the internalized rules and "shoulds and shouldn'ts"  -- even the expectations of others as to how we should be -- keep us from fully expressing who we are.


No matter what our age, none of us knows how long we have left in our lifespans.  In the course of our lives we owe it to ourselves to come to the best understanding of who we are in all our complexity and how to express that self in the world for the benefit of both ourselves and others.  To do this requires being in our integrity, which can require us to break rules on occasion.

The saying "carpe diem" certainly takes on more meaning the older we get.  To truly seize the day, we need to still the internal voice whose first reaction may be "No, you can't because [fill in the blank]."

In short, saying "yes" to life (like old age, as the saying goes) isn't for sissies.

Let's discuss the courage that saying "yes" asks of us as well as the rewards that come from doing so.


There is always a 10-minute guided meditation at the end of the discussion.

Also, over the last several months, it has become a tradition for those of us so inclined to continue our conversation up the street at JP Licks immediately following the monthly discussion.

Please remember to avoid using scented personal products before coming to the meetup as some of our members are chemically sensitive.

A contribution of $5 (or whatever you can afford) toward the meeting room rental and organizer fee is greatly appreciated.  And please change your RSVP before 7 p.m. if you are unable to attend.

There is free parking after 6 p.m. in the lot across the street from the church. To find us, enter the last door on the right at the end of the driveway at the side of the church.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter the last door on the right at the end of the driveway at the side of the church.  We meet in the first or second room on the left.
results.name: Monthly discussion -- see this month's topic below

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are ladies night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Meet at the picnic tables near bouldering area (the one furthest from the cubbies if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the event Host(s) (see RSVP list) from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.

results.description:
This summer series of Irish set dancing classes is for beginners who want to learn the basic movements of set dancing while getting a feeling of accomplishment by dancing whole sets through from beginning to end each night. These are good refresher classes for fairly-new dancers, as well, or "improvers" who want to get more familiar with the various sets. 

We welcome more experienced dancers to join in the classes, as well, but the focus is on teaching beginners; in fact, it really helps the new dancers enjoy the classes more when they have a partner who knows the steps already. We all love sharing what we know and there is great satisfaction in helping newbies learn set dancing.

We teach basic footwork and movements to specific sets during the 8 weeks of classes. We teach one set per night, figure by figure, then dance the whole set at the end of the night. By the end of the series of classes, the new dancer should have enough experience and confidence to join in any set dancing group and start to really enjoy the social and physical benefits of Irish set dancing. 

No partner is needed. Leather-soled shoes are recommended, or shoes that don't stick (most sneakers will stick), as set dancing has a lot of gliding movements. Wear comfortable clothes (think cotton t-shirts and loose pants).

The cost is $8.00 per class* - pay as you go - no need to sign up for the whole series. [*$7 per class for Harrington's regular set dancers] 

Frank and Eileen have been enthusiastically teaching beginner summer classes for several years and will continue to teach the classes, but we also have special guest teachers this summer.
results.name: Antrim Squares & Ballyvourney with Alana - Beg. Set Dance Class at Harrington's

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
We'll attend the CCI Brown Bag discussion with Chip Berlet.  Full title: "White Nationalism, White Supremacy, and White Privilege: How Systems of Oppression are Created and Maintained"

Chip Berlet on whiteness: 

"Whiteness is a racial identity, so as a writer and editor I push to capitalize the term 'White.' I am White. If nothing else it starts a conversation with other White people about what is race and racial identity. I focus on reaching out to White people to confront racism because that's where the main problem hides. Us White folks are very resistant to dealing with race and racism, as Dr. Robin DiAngelo points out in an essay on <a>The Pernicious Impact of 'White Fragility</a>.' The same holds true for systems of oppression based on gender and class."

More info about the discussion is here.

Accessibility Information: Pappenheim Library at Community Change, Inc. is wheelchair accessible with the following limitations.  The door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it. The elevator doors are slightly more than 30 inches wide.  The sixth floor bathrooms are not wheelchair accessible, but the first floor bathroom is.  During regular hours there are usually two tables in the library which limit mobility, but these are often moved elsewhere during discussions.  Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.
results.name: Attend CCI Brown Bag: ...How Systems of Oppression are Created and Maintained

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

A Family-Friendly event!


Demo Night is a chance to see what the top startups are working on, these are the people that are changing the future of business & tech!

August 4th, we will be celebrating the role that a handful of EdTech companies are playing in providing tools for students to and educators to innovate learning experiences, and we'll be in Boston Public Schools's new School Committee Chambers to do it.

Each startup has 5 minutes to demo their product in front of a live audience, it's not a pitch but an opportunity for each startup to explain (and show) what they have been working on. results.description:
Let's Get Coding!! Bring your own device and plan to spend the evening meeting new people, learning Bluemix and coding pre-planned Bluemix labs or your own project.


Our guest speaker, Remko de Knikker, IBM Cloud Technology Evangelist, will give a brief Techtalk on "Back to Bluemix Basics" which will be followed by Hack Hours: Coding time where you can complete introductory Bluemix hands-on labs or make use of the developer expertise in the room to work on your own project.

If you are interested in completing the pre-planned Bluemix labs, please spend a couple minutes before August 4th to complete the following pre-reqs:

Please note that this is a BYOD lab.

You will need a Bluemix and DevOps account for the workshop.  Please follow these instructions prior to coming to the session.


1.  Register for Bluemix for free at:  www.ibm.biz/cloudboston
2.  Fill in the details to create an IBM ID (this ID  will be used to sign in to Bluemix and hub.jazz.net. )
3.  In a few minutes you will receive an email with a button to confirm your account.  Once you click the button you will be redirected to sign in to Bluemix.  This step is required to complete the Bluemix registration process.
4.  Go to https://hub.jazz.net and click on log in at the top right hand corner.
5.  Click on sign in and sign in with the ID you created for Bluemix.
6.  Create an alias. This will be used to authenticate when using git tools or cli and click finish.  You are now ready to start coding on the web.

results.description:
$20 to attend. Please be on time and sign up only if you're positive you can be present.


In this workshop we'll read your work and give you constructive suggestions to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll help you make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!

In a classic David vs. Goliath moment, disruptive entrepreneurs are eyeing the company Michael Bloomberg famously founded with a $10 million Salomon Brothers' severance check.   Ambitious start-ups AND incumbents with an edge are bringing fresh and innovative technology solutions to meet the industry's insatiable appetite for data are gaining ground.  Join friends in the Boston FinTech community and our sponsor Yodlee Interactive and host WorkBar Boston for an insightful discussion over dinner on the big ideas in data.

We are fortunate to have our panel moderated by Jeanine Swatton is Director of Developer Evangelism at Yodlee Interactive.  Joining on in the discussion are President and Co-founder of ChartIQ, Dan Schleifer, and Co-founder of MKT MediaStats, Gideon Ozik.  ChartIQ brings traders a state of the art technical analysis and visualization engine while MKT transforms information extracted from millions of online sources into actionable investment knowledge.

About Yodlee Interactive (YI):  Built on the foundation of Yodlee’s 15 years of aggregated consumer financial data, YI empowers visionary entrepreneurs, partners, and developers to build the next generation of disruptive and innovative FinDat solutions using the award-winning Yodlee platform.

About WorkBar:  WorkBar’s flexible workspaces provide the right balance of concentration and collaboration with others.  With their strong commitment to the Boston FinTech community through their collaboration with DCU,  WorkBar’s space options helps you do your best work.
results.name: Unbundling Bloomberg - New Technologies take on the Data Giant

results.description:
Meet at the historic Bedford Depot at 5:45pm promptly. 

We are going to be cycling the route highlighted above.  It's 34 miles.  The average pace will be 15 MPH.  (Ignore the ride time in the photo.)  I expect to return to our start point a little after 8:00pm.

There will be 2 areas for rest and water - Kate's Corner and Monument Square.

Traffic: This ride is mostly on back roads with little to no traffic. 

Passing vehicles and occasional intersections.  

Please familiarize yourself with the laws and safety techniques of navigating vehicle traffic and intersections:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rU4nKKq02BU

And please familiarize yourself with group riding safety and etiquette: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lK5MPtMrMqU

Level of Difficulty: Please see the elevation graph in the photo; there are several climbs of varying gradients. 

Gradient Levels:

1-6%: A manageable gradient that can cause fatigue over long periods.

7-9%: Starting to become uncomfortable for seasoned riders, and very challenging for new climbers.

10%-15%: A painful gradient, especially if maintained for any length of time.

16%+: Very challenging for riders of all abilities. 

The necessities of cycling:

1) A mechanically sound road bike

Please do pre-ride inspections:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EBKeNOBwaVE

2) A properly fitted helmet

3) Water and Food

4) Tools and supplies for flat repair - levers; spare tubes; a compact pump.

Please review the process of changing a flat tire:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-ZbeR0mJBkk

5) Some form of identification: driver's license; ID bracelet; etc. 

6) Cash or credit card (in case of irreparable mechanical failure requiring a taxi ride back to your car).

7) Eye protection  

***** On all rides this year there will be a donation envelope to collect contributions to help offset the Meet-up hosting charges.  $1 is suggested, but not required.  The organizers thank you in advance for your support ***** 

Here's the link to the route:

https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Historic+Bedford+Depot/42.4863082,-71.2777964/@42.5146469,-71.3869297,12z/data=!4m69!4m68!1m65!1m1!1s0x89e39ec84222516b:0xe1261abe2b4fb762!2m2!1d-71.2771297!2d42.4859552!3m4!1m2!1d-71.326865!2d42.5189203!3s0x89e398fba85fe733:0x70e0b0db2296e319!3m4!1m2!1d-71.3095504!2d42.5458966!3s0x89e398a0141eb327:0xdbb98aa2e37fc180!3m4!1m2!1d-71.3993538!2d42.5679051!3s0x89e3bd5b93ae8db7:0x22392d532789e321!3m4!1m2!1d-71.4166272!2d42.5499254!3s0x89e397c61304e9e3:0xd776c9db0d699092!3m4!1m2!1d-71.4166935!2d42.5491202!3s0x89e397c638b49601:0xedb29383286739e5!3m4!1m2!1d-71.393656!2d42.5503058!3s0x89e397f02300a7d1:0xf08ba360d3e5f0!3m4!1m2!1d-71.3854053!2d42.5518332!3s0x89e397fbcc0bd8d3:0xb99a671842a3936f!3m4!1m2!1d-71.3739744!2d42.545569!3s0x89e3981b137ffabd:0x561f0ec77263ca73!3m4!1m2!1d-71.3894823!2d42.4980944!3s0x89e3975c04b94683:0xe27358ea3ea9165a!3m4!1m2!1d-71.3884334!2d42.4852576!3s0x89e397535f2374ef:0x1a3cc24bfadafaa5!3m4!1m2!1d-71.3489558!2d42.4605549!3s0x89e39a384ee6b09b:0x44ae97151d119f67!3m4!1m2!1d-71.3207086!2d42.5146652!3s0x89e398e371a45a07:0x5efea56f8e29aab9!1m0!3e1?hl=en

results.description:
Level - Middle intermediates (currently playing volleyball regularly, understands and follows basic rules, able to execute basic pass, set and hit skills, and has good fitness).

Do you want to learn about or improve your sand doubles game?  Transition your indoor skills to the beach?  Improve consistency of your game in the sand?  Join us every Tue!  This is the 2nd season and it is still free!

5:45 to 6:30 – Review beach strategies and work through skill building drills

6:00-7:30 – Play beach/sand doubles on a men's height net 

If you have a good quality beach net, court ropes, or ball, please bring it!  More nets = more hits.

I am looking forward to sharing many of the skills and strategies I have learned from clinics I have taken.  FYI I am not a professional/certified coach and my level is as described above, generally know what to do but don't always execute consistently.

Reminder to bring water, sunglasses, bug spray and a beach chair. I will be wearing a gray November Project t shirt (same as profile pic).

ATTENDEES and RSVPs

The way the system works, you have to register for each week.  You can register about 3 weeks in advance.

We are trying to build a group of people who attend all (or most Wed nights).

The way the coaching is organized, it builds on previous weeks, so it is preferable to have the same/similar group each week. 

In order to encourage that, when confirming the RSVPs, I will give preference to participants who have attended previously.

Again, I am doing this to encourage a regular group of people.  I regret any frustration that this may cause if your RSVP status is changed.

DIRECTIONS

Carson Beach (limited free parking available), William Day Blvd, South Boston, http://www.bostonharborwalk.com...­

The net is blue. There are 2 parking lots (one on each side of beach house). Park in the southern lot (closer to State Police barracks) (or the one on the right side of the beach house as you look at the ocean). You will be able to see me and the net from there.

The Foxboro Police department and The Foxboro Jaycees are pleased to announce that they are joining forces with thousands of communities nationwide for the "32nd Annual National Night Out" (NNO), a unique crime and drug prevention event being held on Tuesday, August 5, 2014, from 6 to 9pm on the Foxboro Town Common.

All local residents are invited to participate in this fun family evening designed to heighten awareness of crime and drug prevention efforts in the community; generate support for, and participation in, local anticrime programs; strengthen neighborhood spirit and police-community partnerships; and send a message to criminals letting them know that neighborhoods are organized and fighting back.

Join us for a night of entertainment and awareness!

results.description:
Come out and meet and mingle with other Boston Science Fiction and Fantasy fans at our monthly Social Meetup! We meet for food, drinks, games, and excellent companionship. We'll be at M.J. O'Connor's (the Park Plaza location). They are reserving their entire 150 person back room exclusively for us! I'll bring some board games along. 


More about M.J. O'Connor's here: http://back-bay.mjoconnors.com/

Please keep in mind that there are a couple of M.J. O'Connor locations, we'll be at the Park Plaza location at 27 Columbus Ave. in Boston

LOGISTICS:

* There is no theme or agenda, just people talking about Sci-Fi, Fantasy, and geeky things that we like (and dislike). If you can't come on time, that's fine, we usually have a large group until 8:00 PM. M.J. O'Connors is open until 2am if you want to stay extra late, but they will open up the room to the public at 9:00pm.

* If you have SciFi/Fantasy Books or DVDs that you don't want anymore, feel free to bring them to the meetup and give them away (no sales, please). Be sure to take home anything that isn't claimed before you leave!

* There is no charge for this meetup, but the restaurant that hosts us greatly appreciates your business (and doesn't charge us a room rental fee), so please come hungry (or at least buy a drink). Also, please don't forget to pay your bill before you leave!


TRAVEL:

It's about a 5-10 minute walk from the Park Street T stop (Red and green) and a five minute walk from either Arlington and the Boylston stops on the green line

There are pay parking lots around. For example, the Motor Mart Garage (motormartgarage.com) which is just around the block and is $10 for up to 3 hours, if you come in after 5pm.

Here is a map to the location.

There are some metered parking spots for the those willing to drive around and be patient, but only a few.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the back room on the Park Plaza side of the restaurant. Ask for the sci-fi meetup and they'll show you the way.

Be it a treasure a classical or new wonder, a mystery, a romance, a chick lit or just a good old fashioned trashy novel.  Let’s meet and talk about them all.  One month we will get serious and read a Treasure; the next month we will read a mystery, a new wonder, a romance, a chick lit or just a good old fashioned trashy novel.

This book club has a little something for everyone. This is a perfect setting for everyone who loves reading and talking books.

This month’s read and discussion is a Treasure:  To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee.

Our September book will be Harper Lee new published book Go Set a Watchman. Originally written in the mid-1950s, Go Set a Watchman was the novel Harper Lee first submitted to her publishers before To Kill a Mockingbird

No perfumes please we have members with allergies.

Please meet in the backroom after ordering your food
