results.description:
Come network and hear about how Elasticsearch can be leveraged for Distributed System Analysis as well as installed via Kubernetes. Food and refreshments will be provided on the second floor of WeWork at 745 Atlantic Avenue. A big thanks to WeWork South Station for offering their space and free beer.

Distributed System Analysis using a little TLC and ElasticSearch

A short presentation on our Distributed System Analysis efforts to facilitate indexing Telemetry, Log, and Configuration data to enable deeper analysis of complex distributed systems.

We all are working with ever increasing levels of complexity in our distributed systems as the need for more and more compute power and more storage grows. We describe the work we have done so far to build a warehouse for performance analysis, letting us separate visualization and reporting from collection and normalization, while providing a foundation for applying machine learning techniques. We'll walk through how we collect and normalize Telemetry data into ElasticSearch, along with Log data, and then how we collect and normalize configuration data.  We show some of our work to enable Grafana to visualize the telemetry data, and demonstrate a performance analysis tool, pbench, which wraps benchmarks runs indexing them as discrete results sets, enabling a flexible web UI for visualization and reporting (nvd3 based).

This work is in its very early stages, so there will be lots of duct tape, band-aids, paper-clips, chewing gum, and bees-wax used to keep it all together. :)

Speaker


Peter Portante is a Software Engineer at Red Hat.

Kubernetes: What, Why, and How with ELK


We will discuss what Kubernetes is, and is not, compared to previous deployment systems on physical/virtual machines, Ansible, and OpenStack and explain why Kubernetes is different.To understand how Kubernetes works, we will deploy ELK in a Pod to showcase some of the features Kubernetes provides.


Speaker 

Learnaholic, passionate about Distributed Systems and uptime, Myles Steinhauser is currently focused on ELK, Elixir, Containers and OpenStack.
results.how_to_find_us: Please, sign in at the lobby and come to the 2nd floor
results.name: Distributed System Analysis and Kubernetes

results.description:
Uncertain how to work towards a secure financial future while living out your values? Join Socializing for Justice for a ProfDev on Socially Responsible Investing on August 4, 6:00 - 8:30 PM.


Fee: $10 advance/$20 door - split with trainer 
Limited space - register ahead of time: www.sojust.org 
Credit cards accepted online. Cash only at the door (if space available). 
Newcomers always welcomed!

How do we manage our savings to best sustain ourselves and support our vision of a more just economy? Whether you’re investing now, informing yourself for the future, or organizing a divestment or financial campaign, this is a chance to learn investment basics and discuss all those questions with a local progressive activist and finance professional. No prior knowledge expected: we'll start with basic terms and concepts, and also cover political choices and investment strategies. Participants gain a more intuitive sense of how to use investments, and ideas about how to research and choose between different financial tools without checking your politics at the door.


ABOUT OUR PRESENTER
Joby Gelbspan is a lifelong progressive activist who has dedicated her career to "translating finance for activists." She holds a Master's in Accounting and an MBA, with financial and management experience ranging from non-profit organizations to the investment management industry. She has served on several nonprofit Boards and as CFO and Financial Consultant for grassroots, progressive organizations. She currently coordinates strategic corporate and financial research to support Corporate Accountability International's grassroots campaigns challenging the World Bank and some of the world's largest corporations to halt their abusive practices.

SCHEDULE
6:00-6:30 Socializing - bring your own dinner
6:30-8:30 Training and Q&A

*  DIRECTIONS - The NonProfit Center is located one block from South Station at 89 South Street. The Center is physically accessible through the main lobby.

HELP SPREAD THE WORD!
Invite your friends to the Facebook event.
Join the SoJust Facebook group: http://on.fb.me/SoJust
On Twitter? Follow @SoJust and SoJust's Co-Founder @RobbieSamuels #sojust


_________________________________________________________ 
Socializing for Justice - www.sojust.org
Since 2006, we've been building this great sandbox where we can bring progressives of all stripes together and try out new ideas in this "Movement Moment". Spaces like this are crucial as we start to reframe and build new visions for our movement(s).

SoJust hosts events that draw progressives of all stripes that share common values but may work on different issues. We host monthly socials that allow for the possibility of cross-issue connections and run a monthly ProfDev Series, hosted by The NonProfit Center*, which increases our individual capacity for movement building.

With almost 2700 members and nearly 9 years of creating a diverse cross-issue community in Boston (200+ events!), Socializing for Justice is the best place to find the great people, organizations and community you're looking for while putting the SOCIAL back in social justice.

YES, WE MEAN YOU. We've got members of all ages, races, genders, sexual orientations, levels of activism and professions. We hope you see someone like yourself and meet someone you otherwise wouldn't have.
results.name: ProfDev: Socially Responsible Investing

results.description:
Let's hang out close to home and get to know our neighbors or for those who live outside 02121 head into the community to find out, what's good in the neighborhood.

Playhouse in the Park is another longstanding positive community gathering in a safe setting at which much friend renewing and friend making happens.

National Night Out Dance Party with music by DJs Rudy and Nomadik.

Get there when you can and stay as long as you're able.

Suggest you bring:

1) chair or blanket

2) snacks or supper

3) insect repellent

4) flashlight

5) board games/playing cards

Check out this link for a useful map of the park, http://www.franklinparkcoalition.org/interactive-map/

Here are a few local places from which you can pick up some decent take out or dine in at:

1) Flames (carribean) 469 Blue Hill Ave (617)[masked] two blocks from zoo entrance across from Grove Hall's Mecca mall

2) Stash's (pizza/salads/chicken) 612 Blue Hill Ave (617)[masked] across the street from zoo entrance Public

There is a CVS and Stop and Shop (460 Blue Hill Ave 02121) in the Grove Hall Mecca Mall on Blue Hill Avenue

PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION:
Check out MBTA or Hop Stop to plan your public transportation route.
Take the Orange Line or Commuter Rail to Forest Hills station, then take the number 16 bus to the Franklin Park Zoo.
Take the Orange Line or Commuter Rail to Ruggles station, then take the number 22, 28, 29, 44 or 45 bus to the Franklin Park.
Take the Red line to Andrew station, then take the number 16 bus to the Franklin Park.

DRIVING DIRECTIONS:
Check out Google <a href="http://maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&tab=wl"></a>to plan your driving route

PARKING:
There is parking INSIDE the park near the Shattuck along the main road as well as across from the Blue Hill Ave entrance into the zoo and further down near the golf course. You will have a 10 to 15 minute walk to the Shattuck Picnic Grove area from the zoo and golf parking areas.

Elma Lewis Playhouse in the Park history

For many park users who grew up around Franklin Park, the park is synonymous with "The Playhouse." For twelve years, from 1966 - 1978, Elma Lewis brought summer performances to Franklin Park and helped bring the park back from neglect and disuse. Today, in response to huge community interest and to draw diverse Boston residents into the park, the Franklin Park Coalition has revived the Playhouse. For the last seven years, the City of Boston's portable ParkARTS stage has been brought to the park for concerts, theatre, and dance performances. This ambitious summer arts series has been possible with the involvement of experienced partners: the National Center of Afro-American Artists, First Night Boston's Summer Beat, and ParkARTS. You can look forward to summer concerts every Tuesday morning and evening throughout July and August. Morning shows target summer camps and youth programs but also bring elder groups to the park. All are invited to bring a picnic lunch and stay for the day. FPC's Summer Youth Crew members help direct groups to the site, show them a picnic spot, and can be available to play games or lead a walk in the woods after the show. Evening concerts are for everyone. Families bring a picnic basket and lawn chairs. Neighbors and friends make it a social evening. Performers are local favorites like Ray Greene, Fulani Haynes, Andre Ward, and Valerie Stephens. Playhouse Revival Elma Lewis was adamant that if the performance area is revitalized in her name, it must follow the artistic vision and standards of the original Playhouse in the Park. Ms. Lewis worked tirelessly to ensure that African-American children and community members receive disciplined, skilled artistic training and exposure to the most talented musicians and performers of the day. To carry on in her footsteps, Playhouse in the Park has been re-established as an exciting summer venue for multi-cultural performances. The first summers included gospel concerts, Commonwealth Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, children’s performances for summer camp groups, and theatre workshops for youth directed by Our Place Theatre in Roxbury. The Playhouse in the Park is a cultural partnership between the Franklin Park Coalition, the National Center of Afro-American Artists, and the Boston Parks & Recreation Department. First Night Boston's Summer Beat produces the summer season, which includes five or more Tuesdays with a morning children's event and an evening show for everyone. The 2009 Playhouse summer season was made possible with generous support from ParkARTS, the Boston Foundation, and an anonymous donor and many individual contributors to the Franklin Park Coalition. An exciting 2010 season with daytime and evening Tuesday performances is planned. Today, a playhouse stage is brought in for performances and set up near the Overlook ruins. The Coalition would like to return the Playhouse stage to the scenic ruins Miss Lewis used. Summer arts programming, combined with masonry and landscape restoration, will revive this long-neglected area of the park. Elma Lewis was a cultural icon in Boston's black community until her death in January 2004. She was the founder and director of The Elma Lewis School for Fine and Performing Arts in the 1950s, where thousands of African American children and adults studied until it closed in the 1980s. Miss Lewis, who helped start the Franklin Park Coalition, sought to make the park a community gathering place after years of neglect. Miss Lewis and a group of students cleaned up the rat-infested, garbage-strewn area where Olmsted's Overlook Shelter had burned. They built the Playhouse stage amidst the stone ruins and set up chairs. Thus began a summer concert series that took place every night from July 4th to Labor Day for twelve years. Local performers and national stars graced the Playhouse stage, offering drama, dance, music and poetry, all of the high caliber that Miss Lewis demanded. From Duke Ellington's 4th of July concerts to Olatunji and his African drums closing the season on Labor Day, from Billy Taylor and Odetta to the Boston Ballet, people in Boston were exposed to premier arts.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the ParkARTS stage between White Stadium and back of the Zoo

Who wants to get fit for FREE?

Healthy, Fit & Fun promotes exercise and good health in a fun, group setting. People of all ages and abilities are encouraged to come get fit and make new friends while enjoying the beauty of the Esplanade. The Esplanade Association partners with organizations around Boston to offer a diverse array of expert-led fitness classes. All classes are free and open to the public. Registration is required to participate you may pre- register at the event.


Fusing Latin rhythms and easy to follow moves, nothing is more fun and healthy than a high energy Zumba workout. Routines feature interval training sessions where fast and slow rhythms are combined with resistance training. Come get your groove on and break a sweat on the Esplanade. Classes begin 7/14 Classes sponsored by Healthworks. Refreshments provided by Zico and CLIF.

By pre-registering you will receive email updates with any class changes or cancellations.

Help to support their free public programming - make a donation.

HOSTLESS EVENT- Use the comment sections to find each other.

Lapis blue ocean, white caps, dozens of sailboats of all sizes, balmy breezes, brick side walks, multi-colored flowers spilling from window boxes, quaint little New England homes of all color combinations, brass pineapple door knockers…. Car pooling is recommended!

Public speaking with ease and impact in front of any group.

Imagine standing in front of any audience, feeling absolutely confident and at ease.

Whether you have public speaking anxiety or simply want to express yourself with greater clarity the experience in a Speaking Circle® will guide you toward effortless authenticity

Speaking Circles help:

Business professionals become more effective, authentic and powerful. 

People expand their vision of what life could be like when they are able to

be fully present, confident and authentic. 

People who suffer from stage fright to overcome their fears.

Dexter Nardella

results.description:
We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.

CALLING ALL New C&C Members!

                           Tonight is all about YOU

Bring your favorite game and show us how to play it or just come and meet some new people who share your same passion in game playing.

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford .  There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play games.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome  new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start around 6:30pm or so, early birds can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: New Members Night in Medford

results.description:
Have you always wanted to run a little stronger, a little faster, and have some motivated people around to help push you along? Well now you can have all of those things at the best Track workout ever.

Interest peaked? Read on for more details including the weekly workout.

Meet at the Harvard Track as usual. See what the workout will be below.


View Larger Map

The workout is a simple speed workout designed to add some variety to your run.

The rest of this details the workout and highlights a few things I think are important to remember. Skip it if you would rather just wing it and meet us at the track. We'll fill you in there.

If you have never run on a track before, don't worry if none of this makes sense right now. As much as I will try to prep you, it usually just takes a few laps around the track for all of this to sink in.

The Workout

The workouts vary on a weekly basis and are usually interval based. We sometimes do workouts that are fun and different. Come see what this weeks workout is!

What does that mean?

1. The distances (200, 400, 800, etc.) are the distances we run on the track. Each lap around the track is 400 meters.

2. Each lap is supposed to be run at a certain speed, based on your 5k pace. Don't know what your 5k pace is? Read my instructions below to calculate your 5k pace.

*3. The recovery interval (RI), which is indicated in parentheses, may be a specified timed interval or a distance that you walk/jog.

Things to remember

Track workouts are supposed to be FUN! Don't be intimidated or dread a track workout. This is supposed to be a fun supplement to your other "normal" runs. With all of us out there encouraging each other it should be a blast.

Bring a running stopwatch/wristwatch if you have one! Using the start/lap/stop function will help you pace yourself on each lap.

Don't push it! If something hurts or starts to feel tight, don't risk an injury because you ran too hard on your first track workout of the summer. We have plenty of time to ease in...

Bring water for the end!!!

5k pace instructions

Decide how fast you would like to run a 5k. Choose a time that is reasonable yet challenging. Convert that time to seconds, and divide the seconds by 12.5 (the number of 400 meter laps it takes to run 5k). That is your 5k pace.

As an example, I might decide a reasonable yet challenging goal time for a 5k is 24 minutes.

24 minutes x 60 seconds per minute = 1440 seconds

1440 seconds divided by 12.5 laps in a 5k ~= 115 seconds / lap

This means that I will run the workout according to a pace of 115 seconds / lap.

I will also have pacing charts available at the track, so don't fret.

Blog
results.name: Track Tuesday

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 8-16 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event. Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

results.description:
Gentlepeople,

We're meeting Tuesday August 4th at our NEW LOCATION in Wellesley.  Join us!

This coming Tuesday, on August 4, your Boston Network Users Group, BNUG, will meet at Mass Bay Community College in Wellesley Hills to learn about the Cryptolocker virus and Using Wordpress as a business tool.  As usual, admission is FREE and open to all.  Munchies and Intermingling (M&I) starts at 6:30pm, the meeting will start at 7pm and must end by 8:30pm. 

IMPORTANT: You need to have a (free) parking permit and directions.  These are located online (print yours) at http://www.bnug.org/parkingpermit

Please let me know if you plan to come or even if you may come so we can have enough space and munchies.  Thanks.

About the meeting: 

Adam will lead a discussion on

•  The Cryptolocker virus: what it means, how to prevent it 

•  Using Wordpress as a business tool, including pairing it with PayPal for eCommerce

If time permits he may also address MS Outlook functions including archiving, using categories, imap vs pop, and data recovery.  Or other topics that are brought up.

About the speaker Adam Frost

Adam Frost works as the coordinator of Computer Care and Learning, an educationally-oriented computer helping company. While some of our colleagues and competitors encourage “outsourcing” of all computer care to them, we encourage our customers to get to know their computers and train their staff in computer care. We find this helps our customers develop deep skills in computer use as a key part of business strategy and action.

Computer Care and Learning has a longstanding internship program, where we train people to be skilled computer helpers, and we also help run the Get Connected! clinic, which provides refurbished computers to customers with low and moderate incomes.

To learn more, come to the meeting, call us at[masked], or email [masked]

FINALLY, thanks for reading this far.  I'm always open to your comments and suggestions, and even your questions and clever jokes (especially the latter).

Regards,
-steve
Steve Isenberg
President, BNUG


PS: MBCC Students are encouraged to join us!
results.name: BNUG Meeting: Cryptolocker and Wordpress

We will be either at or around the bar and then move to a round table. Ask the bartenders if you can not find us or are a newbie. All members should wear Red Sox Baseball hats.

Go Sox

This movie looks hilarious!!

" Filmmaker Judd Apatow (The 40-Year-Old Virgin, Knocked Up, This Is 40) directs Trainwreck, starring and written by breakout comedic actress Amy Schumer (“Inside Amy Schumer”). Since she was a little girl, it’s been drilled into Amy’s head by her rascal of a dad (Colin Quinn) that monogamy isn’t realistic. Now a magazine writer, Amy lives by that credo—enjoying what she feels is an uninhibited life free from stifling, boring romantic commitment—but in actuality, she’s kind of in a rut. When she finds herself starting to fall for the subject of the new article she’s writing, a charming and successful sports doctor named Aaron (Bill Hader), Amy starts to wonder if other grown-ups, including this guy who really seems to like her, might be on to something. The comedy Trainwreck also stars Brie Larson, John Cena, Tilda Swinton and LeBron James."

See the trailer here:

results.description:
The Yoga of Equal Taste teaches that, while life seems to be a series of ups and downs, joys and sorrows, highs and lows, there is a thread of deep continuity running through it. In other words, joy and sorrow, rather than being entirely different, have an element of equal taste. To find that place of equal taste is part of the path of spiritual maturity. It is not to “flat line” all our diverse experiences, but to discover stability and groundedness within them. In this evening teaching, we will explore the Yoga of Equal taste, as it relates to our meditation practice and to life.

Please join us for a session of natural meditation in the Tibetan Buddhist traditions of Dzogchen and Mahamudra. More details and information about our group can be found at the following URL:

http://www.naturaldharma.org

Please note: most of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending than are signed up using this web site.
results.name: Equal Taste with Lama Willa Miller

Guest Speaker Bio: Stephen Miller is one of the original founders of Strongbrook REIC.  Stephen Miller has been General Manager at a leading home inspection company.  He has also worked as a licensed loan officer, and is a recognized industry expert on “compassionate financing,” a subject on which he has taught numerous classes. 

Strongbrook

Over the past decade Strongbrook has become a leader in creating and managing real estate within investment and retirement portfolios. 

Strongbrook’s 10 year history of producing positive results with real estate, during market highs, crashes and lows, is due to its proprietary short-term buy and hold strategy of purchasing investment-grade single family rental homes in High Equity Growth Markets, as well as in Cash Flow markets.

By understanding how to identify, and when to deploy Equity Growth Strategies and/or High Positive Cash Flow Strategies, Strongbrook is able to sustain growth and create positive cash flow for its clients by navigating in and out of these markets.
results.name: Create, manage, protect and grow wealth through turn key real estate.

This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.description:
Join us for our next FREE Dating and Relationship Teleseminar

"The Sexually Intelligent Single Adult"

with Guest Speaker Roy Biancalana, Relationship Coach and Author

WHEN: Tuesday, August 4th, 2015 from 8:30 PM to 9:45 PM (ET)
SPEAKER: Roy Biancalana, Relationship Coach and Author
WHO'S INVITED: This Teleseminar is Open to EVERYONE 
HOW MUCH: Complimentary! 
HOW TO RSVP: http://predatingteleseminar.eventbrite.com 

"The Sexually Intelligent Single Adult"
with Guest Speaker Roy Biancalana, Relationship Coach and Author

Most people are familiar with “IQ” (Intelligence Quotient) and some are familiar with “EQ” (Emotional Quotient). But very few are familiar with “SQ” (Sexual Quotient).

In this critically important tele-seminar, hosted by relationship expert and #1 best-selling author, Roy Biancalana, you will learn how to be smart and savvy with your sexual energy so that you can attract a meaningful, lasting relationship.

Some topics to be discussed include:

To do it or not to do it—when to get physical How to spot and avoid “players” How to communicate your sexual boundaries Why size really does matter How to be sexually attractive (hint: it’s different for men and women) How to handle your sexual energy when you don’t have a partner What it means to be “great in the sack”  PLUS All attendees will receive:

One free 30 Minute Exploratory Coaching Session Special discounts from on Roy's many programs And more! ABOUT OUR SPEAKER - Samantha Jayne

Roy Biancalana: is known as "The Intimacy Guru," and is a nationally recognized leader in the field of attraction, intimacy and conscious relationships. He appears regularly on Fox35 TV in Orlando, FL as their relationship expert and is the author of the book, "A Drink with Legs" sold worldwide.

Roy is a certified relationship coach, spiritual teacher and was a PGA Tour player. His passion is working with men and women who are committed to awakening to their true spiritual nature and experiencing the love life they most desire. He specializes in supporting single people in attracting the love of their lives and also helping those who are in committed partnerships experience a deeper level of intimacy. He has clients all over the world and coaches by phone, Skype or in person.

PAST TELESEMINAR REPLAYS AND BONUSES: Missed one of our past free Teleseminars? At the bottom of our current teleseminar information page is a list of all past seminars and links to the free recordings! http://www.pre-dating.com/teleseminar/

We'll meet at the Park across from 181 Market Street in historic downtown Lowell and head off.  We'll walk for about an hour and end up at a diner or coffee shop for breakfast.

Weather guidelines - about 20 degrees is the coldest I will tolerate.  I don't mind light precipitation, but you won't find me out if it's really coming down.

I've been doing these walks most weekday morning since February of 2015, and folks are beginning to join me.  I recently weeded out the member list so that new folks could join.  If your name was removed and you'd like to walk, please re-join or simply show up.

results.description:
Requirements:

• Must be a Massachusetts licensed real estate agent to attend.
• Seating is limited to the first 15 registrations


Most real estate agents have 2 revenue streams: 

1. Working with buyers to purchase a home for them to live in and

2. Working with sellers by listing and their home. 

Learn how to add additional revenue streams to your real estate business by attending this lunch and learn event hosted by Tom Cafarella of Ocean City Development. The presentation will focus on adding additional revenue streams to your real estate brokerage business including:


1. Making money by helping us acquire properties: Think it would be easier to approach an expired listing or FSBO with an offer in hand from a cash buyer?  We'll show you how to easily get in front of more sellers.
2. Our Automated Short Sale System:  Learn how to capitalize on short sales while keeping your sanity.  Our automated short sale program allows agents to spend a very limited amount of time and effort while maximizing their commissions.
3. Buyer Lead Overflow: we don't work with buyers, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't.  Learn how working with an investor can provide you with an overflow of buyer leads and how we generate these leads(mostly by accident).
4. Learn how to make money by wholesaling properties & raising capital: we'll show you how to easily and effectively add these two revenue streams to your real estate business.

As an added bonus, we will be reviewing our best practices and systems to allow you to leverage your time and efforts in 2015.  

Tom is a principle of Ocean City Development and is head of acquisitions. Tom has been on the front lines of Ocean City Development's team, and has acquired over 62 properties to fix and flip over the past 12 months. Environment & Structure of Event: The presentation will be held in our conference room in Wakefield and we will be providing lunch and refreshments. Seating is limited to the first 15 registrants and the presentation will be followed by a Question and Answer session. The presentation and Question and answer will end at approximately 12pm and for those who want to stick around or have additional 1 on 1 questions we will be ending at 12:30pm.
results.name: Making Money w/Ocean City - Lunch & Learn - Creating  Additional Revenue Streams

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
We need to get the following information into the hands of EVERY DIRECTOR of a KILL SHELTER in the US as well as BOARD MEMBERS and supporters of those shelters.   Due to a generous grant from a supporter, the NO KILL ADVOCACY CENTER (not to be confused w/organizations with similar names) is making the following offer. We need YOUR HELP! Please post to the Facebook page of EVERY KILL "Shelter" you can think of- as well as every pro-animal group.  Please also email info to shelter directors & board members of Kill "shelters" (contact info below).   Please make it clear that you are NOT a member of any group but are writing as a private citizen.   IMPORTANT:  Always be extremely polite & assume they will stop the killing once they understand how it can be done.

We CAN SEE a NO KILL AMERICA in our lifetimes!
---

FREE to a GOOD (or bad) SHELTER

Are you a SHELTER DIRECTOR? Attorney Nathan Winograd, former Director of Operations for the SF SPCA and Director of the No Kill Advocacy Center, would like to show you- FREE - how ANY SHELTER can become NO KILL - while TURNING A HEFTY PROFIT! For your FREE COPY of the book "REDEMPTION- the No Kill Revolution in America" as well as a your FREE CD with over 200 documents, including “how to” guides, sample policies and procedures that will guide you, step by step, in implementing this proven model, please send a letter on official letterhead to:

No Kill Advocacy Center
6114 La Salle Ave. #837
Oakland CA 94611

The fine print: No emails. U.S. addresses only. Only one per shelter. Under the terms of the grant, this offer does not apply to foster-based rescue groups. While supplies last. For a schedule of screenings of documentary film REDEMPTION: The No Kill Revolution in America (based on the book), please go to www.nokill.org

Note:  (copied from original discussion on August's "virtual event"): a list of the 10 highest kill shelters is available here:   http://www.advocateforsavingdogs.org/highkillshelterslist.html

I posted on lots of sites and wrote the director of a shelter in Augusta, GA - will continue on down the list. I think it might be good strategy, though, to start with the shelters in your town and then state. You go to webpages to find staff members and mail them. I would cc several people at a shelter- my logic being that maybe *one* will be receptive. We can also email members on the boards of directors

PLEASE:  remember to be extremely polite, and always assume the directors are just not aware of the no-kill model and would certainly implement it if they knew how.

IMPORTANT:  Please make it clear that you are writing as a private citizen, and not as part of an organized effort

For more discussion on which states have been covered, etc, please see original discussion at august's virtual "save lives" event.

WE CAN DO THIS!

results.description:
Greetings Photographers!

You can learn to take better photos by looking at the work of others. Wed. nights entrance to the Museum of Fine Arts is FREE!!!! Join us as we go check out the snapshot exhibit and have a discussion. Then we will take some photos of our own all around the museum and end up having "refreshments" at the cafe to look at our work.  If you are new to the group this is a great way to meet the other members and have some fun. 

This is a free photo social but you do need to RSVP and to show up if you say you will be attending. Being a no show is a no no in this group :)  You will need to arrive and get a free ticket to enter the museum. Then come in to the area of the New American Cafe and find us at the green glass sculpture. More info will be provided once you RSVP.  Suzanne  

Description of the exhibit directly from the MFA website:"Spanning the 20th century, the almost 300 found photographs in “Unfinished Stories” depict a century of image-making by private photographers. “A quick shot fired by a hunter without deliberate aim,” reads the original definition of a snapshot from the early 19th century. The term “snapshot,” popularized shortly after the invention of Kodak’s box camera in the 1880s, came to describe photographs of everyday life using a handheld camera. Speedy new technology boosted the ability to create a visual diary, commemorating events and personal moments, road trips and holidays. Now, more than a century later, these once ubiquitous and now historic, silver gelatin photographs are rapidly being replaced by Instagram and other digital forms of photography, hence a new appreciation for such photographs." 

“Unfinished Stories” celebrates a century of snapshots from the Peter J. Cohen Collection of amateur photographs. An avid collector, Cohen rescued more than 50,000 lost, discarded, or disowned personal photographs, culled from flea markets, antique shops, galleries, eBay, and private dealers. As he sifted and sorted through his finds, Cohen discovered mesmerizing, often humorous, shots removed from their original context: People at Play, Photographers’ Shadows, Double Exposure, Couples, Oddities, and Hula Madness. These pictures reveal the lives of strangers through intimate exposures, telling a story, or as Cohen puts it, “a teeny part of a story that remains unfinished.”

“Unfinished Stories” celebrates unexpected discoveries in these compelling visual objects, each representative of what makes photography such a rich form of expression and a deep cultural symbol for everyone who’s had to stand still and say, “Cheese!”

Above: Unidentified photographer, American, about 1950s. Gelatin silver print. Gift of Peter J. Cohen.

Hope to see you on Wed! Join us when you can.  Suzannem

results.description:
Hi All!
A number of you have shown interest in a weekday evening meetup in the downtown Boston area. Here it is! Please come and join us for a casual 2 hours ASL social on Wednesdays from 5:30 to 7:30 pm.


WHO: All who are interested in ASL are welcome to join us. Whether you're Deaf or hearing, beginner or fluent ASL user, we're here to share and socialize in this beautiful language.

WHERE: We'll be in the City Place Food Court in Dept of Transportation Building (use entrance on Boylston Street across street from Boylston Street T stop or entrance on Stuart Street) . Since we'll most likely be the only group of people signing, we should be pretty easy to spot.

RULES: Voices off, use paper and pen if you need to--this helps us learn and its Deaf friendly


RESOURCES: For those of you who are new to ASL and want to come prepared, here are some very good websites with free online classes.

http://www.westwoodasl.com/ http://www.lifeprint.com/ http://www.start-american-sign-language.com/

RSVP: Please RSVP for the meetup that you will be attending so we know how many people to expect.

CONTACT: Please feel free to contact host (Sean) if you have any questions or concerns. Hope to see you there! :)

Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who have purchased the $10 intro pack get a $10 deduction from $110 membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest MBTA stop is South Station on the Red Line.

The ability to overlook how the other Munchkin players have stopped you from getting past level 9 ten times in a row and suddenly your down to level 8. Just breath, in and out, in and out.

This is a special mid-week training event. Please note the special time and location. We will meet in front of the cafe at 6:00PM and head over to Spy Pond Field / Wellington Street for the workout.

Massachusetts Ave traffic will be VERY SLOW during this time, please expect to take extra 30-60 minutes if you are going to drive to Arlington center.

Parking: Please DO NOT park at the Kickstand Cafe parking lot.  There is a large, metered parking lot across the street. Or, you can also try to find spots without  meters a few blocks away from Arlington center. 

Registration fees:  If you have not yet registered and paid the fees, please do so at this page.  http://www.teamaidasha.org/register Please contact us at [masked] if you have any questions.


Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html


About AID-Boston

Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at: www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT

Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at: http://www.ashanet.org/mit/

results.description:
You’ve constructed a model and are getting significant p-values. Everything looks good, but then your algorithm starts losing money. Sometimes the ways that models are constructed can lead to a complete breakdown in the statistics used to evaluate them. We will show some common cases of this and discuss warning signs.

This talk is part of Quantopian’s Summer Lecture Series. We are currently developing a quant finance curriculum and will be releasing clone-able notebooks and algorithms to go along with this lecture.


Pizza and beer will be served.

Speaker Details

Delaney Granizo-Mackenzie will be presenting. Delaney is an engineer at Quantopian whose focus is on how Quantopian can be used as a teaching tool. After studying computer science at Princeton, Delaney joined Quantopian in 2014. Since then he has led successful course integrations at MIT Sloan and Stanford, and is planning on expanding to many more schools this fall. Delaney’s background includes 7 years of academic research at a bioinformatics lab, and a strong focus on statistics and machine learning. 

Want to learn more about Quantopian? Visit us at: www.quantopian.com.

results.name: Quantopian Summer Lecture: You Don't Know How Wrong You Are Part 2

Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.

results.description:
Reality Computing Boston is BACK with another FREE event and four awesome cutting-edge presentations and demos from startups and researchers in 3d printing and visualization from Harvard, MIT, MassChallenge and Autodesk. Check out this agenda then mark your calendars for the evening of August 5, 6-8:30 at MassChallenge in the Innovation and Design Building in Boston's Innovation District.

---

SPARK and EMBER


Let's make 3D printing work! Have you wanted to learn more about the Spark open platform for building better 3D printing software, hardware, materials and services? Or the Spark investment fund supporting startups in this area? Kevin Tracy from the Autodesk Spark platform team will cover all of this and more. Plus he'll have an Ember 3d printer on hand to check out.

VOXEL8


Harvard startup and MassChallenge alum Voxel8 is developing the world's first 3D electronics printer. Travis Busbee, Co-founder and Materials Lead for Voxel8 will share their story and why MIT Tech Review recently named them one of the 50 smartest companies of 2015.

LUMII


Current MassChallenge finalist and MIT startup Lumii is developing the first commercial light field display engine. From research out of the MIT Media Lab, they are fundamentally changing the way people experience the display of digital 3D information. They are replacing display optics with software. Curious? Come and find out more.

JOHN KLEIN and LAIA MOGAS SOLDEVILA, from the MIT Media Lab 


John is an Architect at the MIT’s Media Lab where he directs cross-disciplinary teams to develop technologies for architectural manufacturing. Working with the Mediated Matter Group, John is developing an additive manufacturing platform to print optically transparent glass building components, which perform as a template to host biological matter. Through his firm, John Klein Design, he is also working in the area of advanced materials and manufacturing to make novel structures at the intersection of design, engineering and science. Whatever John has to tell us about is sure to be interesting!

Image credit: (left) Mediated Matter Group's Chitosan Printing (right) Mediated Matter Group & MIT Glass Lab's Glass Printing 

Laia is an Architect and a Researcher at the MIT Media Lab, focusing on design and advanced digital fabrication of bio-based and biologically-inspired material systems. In[masked] she was awarded research grants to pursue the 'Architecture, Energy and Environment’ program at UPC BarcelonaTech and the 'Master of Science in Architecture Studies' at MIT Design Computation Group. Since 2008, she co-leads the DumoLab design studio. Laia's work has been exhibited at international design and architecture expos and museums.


---


There will be plenty of time for networking with innovative, entrepreneurial, like-minded individuals from the Boston tech scene, and some time at the end for brief shout-outs from attendees. Pizza and appropriate beverages provided.

Networking and food start at 6pm, presentations from 7 to 8pm, networking and refreshments continue until 8:30pm.

Directions to the venue | Parking within a short walk is available at the BRA-EDIC Parking Garage | Reality Computing Blog

The Boston Volunteers partners with Commonwealth Shakespeare Company, a not-for-profit theatre company dedicated to performing the works of Shakespeare for free across the Boston area. CSC’s annual Free Shakespeare on the Common depends on volunteers to keep this Boston tradition top-quality for all patrons.

Thank you for your interest in volunteering for CSC’s 20th season of Free Shakespeare on the Common with the production of King Lear. Volunteer responsibilities include passing out playbills, setting up and breaking down chairs and tents, selling merchandise, collecting surveys, cleaning up at the end of the night, and performing other duties assigned by our House Management Staff. This year's production of King Lear plays July 22 to August 9.

A Boston Volunteers t-shirt will be given to each volunteer to wear at the performance. Individuals who are volunteering at multiple performances will only receive one t-shirt.

A couple other groups will be joining us including: 

Do you live near Brookline: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers 

Don't you like to do good: Boston Volunteers

Are you a Foodie: Favorite Boston Restaurants

We anticipate volunteering with you, :)

Josh and friends

The Boston Volunteers

Big enough to deliver, small enough to care

Learn more: www.BostonVolunteer.org

results.description:
Commonwealth Shakespeare Company's 20th season of free Shakespeare on Boston Common will present King Lear for the very first time.

King Lear follows the journey of an aging king, faced with his own mortality and mental decline, who tries to secure the legacy of his kingdom by dividing it amongst his three daughters. Only through loss--of status, of love, of loyalty--does King Lear learn what is truly resonant at the end of a life.

“King Lear is one of Shakespeare’s monumental plays,” says Steven Maler, CSC's Founding Artistic Director. “There’s good reason I’ve waited 20 years to take it on. As with the greatest of Shakespeare’s history plays, Lear blends the political and the personal, interweaving a country’s destiny with the very human frailties of those charged with shepherding its future. The play reveals what it means to be human--our responsibilities to ourselves, our family and our fellow human beings--as well as true loyalty and loyalty as pretense for deceit, and the struggles in times of succession and transition that are as resonant today as they were four hundred years ago." 

http://commshakes.org/performances/performance/97


http://commshakes.org/about/faq


You are welcome to bring a blanket and or short beach/lawn chair and food though there will be food trucks at the site and you can rent a lawn chair for $5 on either side of the stage.  

We will meet early so as to secure a good viewing area for our party and because many people stake out their spot 2-3 hours early.  

At 7 pm, an hour before the performance begins, there will be a Greenshow featuring actors from its CSC's apprentice training program. The Greenshow is a lively and fun prelude to an evening's performance, meant to prepare the audience for the main stage event--and runs approximately 30 minutes.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in front of the Thinking Cup Cafe across the street from the Common--and walk to the Parkman Bandstand area.
results.name: Shakespeare on the Common: King Lear

results.description:
Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

Both Routes A and B are flat to slightly rolling, and distances are about 5 miles. Surfaces are mixed, including packed dirt, grass, gravel, wooden walkways, and paved streets. Trail shoes, however, are not required.

results.description:
WE ARE BACK IN DAVIS SQUARE FOR TONIGHT, PLEASE TAKE NOTE OF THIS.

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
** Walk down the driveway to the rear of the building; we have a private entrance at ground level. **

Come and join us for an evening of fun and shared energy. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in Boston?

At TurnON, we play three communication games, and you can participate at whatever level feels good to you. Imagine meeting new people in an environment where they feel comfortable to be themselves; a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation. That's what we have created. TurnON events give you the opportunity to look deeper into yourself, through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses. What comes up might surprise you! It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. At the end of the evening, we will give you a brief description of the practice of Orgasmic Meditation and information on where to learn more. The games we play at TurnON events are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without actually doing the practice (or touching anyone, or removing any clothing!). ** We start on time, so please arrive by 7:20.**

$10, payable at the door.
results.name: TurnON Boston!

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Wednesday

results.description:
Presented by Boston Landmarks Orchestra at DCR Hatch Shell on Boston Esplanade.

This annual performance at the Hatch Shell by Boston’s medical community orchestra, always an innovator in programming and community engagement.

The Golden Age of Italian opera is about passion writ large. Its music now occupies a central place on the concert stages of the world. The thrilling voices of two stars of American opera join a coalition of outstanding Boston-area choruses. One of Fellini’s greatest films luxuriates in the festive and lyrical music of Nino Rota—who later composed music for The Godfather and musicians from the famous Honk! festival of activist street bands..

Barbara Shirvis, soprano
Stephen Powell, baritone
One City Choir
Back Bay Chorale (Scott Allen Jarrett, music director)
North End Music and Performing Arts Center
Honk! Festival Musicians

Ruggero Leoncavallo Pagliacci: Prologue
Pietro Mascagni Cavalleria rusticana: Intermezzo & “Regina coeli”
Giuseppe Verdi Otello: “Dove guardi” & Iago’s Credo    Giuseppe Verdi
Giacomo Puccini Tosca: Te Deum
Nino Rota La strada: Ballet Suite (excerpts)
Verdi Nabucco: Overture and “Va, pensiero”
Verdi Aida: Ballet and Triumphal March


HOSTLESS EVENT

venue.name: Out of the Blue Art Gallery

results.description:
A night of boundary dissolution, where we find all antennas both transmit and receive. Band, audience, ambiance, sound check, performance?? We dance in joy that is experiencing the absurdity of these distinctions.

Sonic Osmosis is our attempt to leak through the walls that box in free improv music and art.

Take a bunch of musicians and artists, some of whom have never met, herd them into one space and allow them to freely interact -- no set times, no sound check, no stage, and no guarantee that an audience member won’t grab your bongos and start beating on them!

Leave your expectations at the door, and pay attention! Someone might be talking to you from the other side of the room. Wander through the space to hear different mixes of what's happening, and if you feel inspired, jump into the fray! Do a dance! Recite a poem! Make some noise! Or just chill on the couch...no one will shine an unwanted spotlight on you.

Sonic Osmosis is a monthly series at Out of the Blue Too Gallery (541 Mass. Ave., Cambridge, MA).

Admission to our events is a $3-10 sliding scale for “audience members” (those who do not declare their art tools at the door), but we also ask the “artists” to donate to the gallery as well, cuz we all in this together! All money goes to the gallery, because this place rocks and we want to keep it around for a long, long time.

If you’d like to attend or participate, please join us!
results.how_to_find_us: https://www.facebook.com/groups/sonicosmosis
results.name: Sonic Osmosis #3 - Improv Free-For-All

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 1 Corinthians!

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Groupas we meet to discuss Chapters 13, 14, and 15 of Keynes' "General Theory", as well as Chapters 14 and 15 of Hazlitt's line-by-line critique of it titled "Failure of the New Economics." The readings are not required to attend our meeting.

READINGS:

"The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money" by J.M. Keynes: Chapters 13, 14, and 15 
http://bit.ly/1QDOIeY

"The Failure of the New Economics" by Henry Hazlitt: Chapters 14 and 15
http://bit.ly/1RKJIZk

STUDY QUESTIONS:

1.  How does Keynes “state of confidence” relate to the marginal efficiency of capital and the investment demand schedule?

2.  How does Hazlitt refer to Keynes’s contempt for the nature of human action?

3.  Hazlitt complains that Keynes make misguided statements from which he asserts incorrect suppositions: which stock market phenomenon does Hazlitt use to contradict Keynes’s view that investors lack market knowledge?

4.  What is Keynes’s view of stock value, and, how does his view point contrast with Austrian view of asset valuation.

5.  In Keynes’s view, if the individual is “unqualified” to invest and make investment decisions, who should be making investment decisions; and, what will distinguish the successful entrepreneur from the unsuccessful?

6.  Keynes appears to be concerned with short term economic and financial issues, how does Keynes deride deride long term concerns?

7.  How does Hazlitt mock Keynes’s contempt for, and misunderstanding of, speculation?

8.  Does Keynes make a distinction between speculation and enterprise; and, how is this distinction in conflict with the Austrian viewpoint?

9.  How does Keynes define the rate of interest; and, how does this definition conflict with the Austrian definition?

10.  What are Keynes’s three divisions of liquidity preference; and, which of these is “wicked?”

11.  How does Hazlitt propose preventing speculative booms?
results.how_to_find_us: You can reach our Director of Events, Natalya, @ 774-284-0420.
results.name: Liquidity and Interest

results.description:
So, What Do Ya Think?

No, Really – What DO You Think? Most of us are on auto-pilot most of the time. We’re in the back of the car, kind of like Miss Daisy, and our unconscious thoughts are doing the driving. How often do you end up someplace or have an experience and think, “this is not quite what I had in mind……” If you truly believe that you create your reality, it might be helpful to know if you’re really doing the driving, or what’s driving you.
This workshop is presented by Rev Sam Mcartin
starting promptly at 7pm $5
results.name: What Do You Think?

results.description:
Come join us every first Wednesday of the month for our friendly and casual social get together where we discuss the latest news and events in the atheist and secular community and strike up various conversations relating to atheism (philosophy, humanism, a/theology, politics, and scientific skepticism). We also like to talk about just about anything else of interest (geek culture, technology, pets, etc.) and chill with like-minded people like yourself.

If you are new to the group, please come in and say hi. If you are nervous, don't be. Many of us had the same feeling the first time and then decided to come a second, third, etc. Feel free to come alone or with a friend or more. Just come. We enjoy having those conversations that you may find difficult to have with your family, friends, or coworkers. You may be surprised what friends you will find here.

See you soon.
results.how_to_find_us: We're usually at the large table in the back.
results.name: Atheists of Greater Lowell Monthly Social Meetup

results.description:
Fitness is about more than physical exercise -- it's an opportunity to experience life as you never have before. Join acclaimed yoga instructor David Magone as he pushes the boundaries of yoga into the world of rave lights and electronic music. 

On August 5, OBERON is transforming into a rave yoga studio. The evening starts with David leading a 90 minute thigh-scorching sequence of standing postures, light-as-air backbends, deep hip opening practices, and guided meditations. After class, stick around for special performances, drinks at the bar, and an open dance floor with a live DJ. If you're looking for this summer's hottest evening activity, look no further. Grab your body paint and yoga mat and get ready to rave.

results.description:
Most Wednesdays we gather for an open gaming night at the Panera in Porter Square. This event is open to anyone, and usually doesn't have any sort of pre-arranged agenda -- anything you can bring is fair game, provided you can get it done in three hours!

* Your gallant host almost always brings something to play, and takes requests if you get said request to him by Tuesday night at the latest. Behold the collection: http://www.bgg.cc/collection/user/CmdrOverbite?gallery=large&rankobjecttype=subtype&rankobjectid=1&columns=title%7Cstatus%7Cversion%7Crating%7Cbggrating%7Cplays%7Ccomment%7Ccommands&geekranks=%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09Board+Game+Rank%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09&own=1&objecttype=thing&ff=1&subtype=boardgame

* Due to logistical concerns and a desire to keep peace with the management (who have been notably chill thus far about a bunch of freeloading nerds taking up their table space), I have set a limit of twelve attendees on these events going forward. I doubt this will be much of an issue, given our typical attendance numbers.

* Because our events tend to be small, and the games we typically play tend to be long, if at all possible, please let us know if you plan to be more than a couple of minutes late so that we don't launch into something without you. Likewise, if you're planning on arriving more than a half-hour late, you should be aware that it may not be possible to include you in a game. You're welcome to come by and hang out but the chances are better than even that we'll be hip-deep in gaming goodness by the time you arrive.

* Please be respectful of our hosts; stay mindful of closing time and throw 'em some business if you're hungry.

* Have fun and roll high!
results.how_to_find_us: We usually meet on the lower level -- look for the games!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
Hi, folks. Sorry for the late notice...

The Back Bay Chorale has been invited by the amazing Boston Landmarks Orchestra to sing with the One City Choir and two other choirs for "Italian Night on the Esplanade!" (a free concert for all...)

The music is lovely, the setting historic and the weather looks perfect. Celebrate summer with us on the Charles River Wednesday night!

The Golden Age of Italian opera is about passion writ large. Its music now occupies a central place on the concert stages of the world. The thrilling voices of two stars of American opera join a coalition of outstanding Boston-area choruses. One of Fellini’s greatest films luxuriates in the festive and lyrical music of Nino Rota—who later composed music for The Godfather and musicians from the famous Honk! festival of activist street bands..

Barbara Shirvis, soprano
Stephen Powell, baritone
One City Choir
Back Bay Chorale (Scott Allen Jarrett, music director)
North End Music and Performing Arts Center
Honk! Festival Musicians

Ruggero Leoncavallo Pagliacci: Prologue
Pietro Mascagni Cavalleria rusticana: Intermezzo & “Regina coeli”
Giuseppe Verdi Otello: “Dove guardi” & Iago’s Credo Giuseppe Verdi
Giacomo Puccini Tosca: Te Deum
Nino Rota La strada: Ballet Suite (excerpts)
Verdi Nabucco: Overture and “Va, pensiero”
Verdi Aida: Ballet and Triumphal March
results.name: Back Bay Chorale & One City Choir at Boston Landmarks Orchestra Italian Night!

results.description:
Let's go for Central and South American food. 

www.laqchara.com 

This little hole in the wall is a sister place to Coffee, Tea, and Me, one of my favorite lunch and coffee spots in Melrose. La Qchara is closer to the Wakefield border, and because it is so small I'm limiting the RSVP's to 6. I'm planning to call a few days in advance to make sure they can accomodate; they are open Wednesdays until 8:30 PM. 

Funny story, they told me about their new restaurant when I went into Coffee, Tea, and Me, and I googled it and googled it and googled it but I couldn't find it. Ends up I was using the actual Spanish spelling, La Cuchara (the word for spoon) and didn't get the literal  Q business of how they chose to name their restaurant. So of course I never found it on google.  

I might be able to get there by 7:00, but because it is tight I'm saying I'll be there by 7:15. Hold a table if you get there before I do. As always, I've got bananagrams if people want to linger. 

As usual, please don't RSVP and then don't come. I don't want to play bananagrams all by myself, nor munch of my share of yucca fries and fish tacos while staring at some empty chairs, and it kind of sucks when people just don't show up. If you can't come I just ask that you un RSVP yourself before the dinner starts, preferably earlier, and I won't count you as a NO SHOW. 

...because you wouldn't want to deny someone else the experience of Central/ South American food.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the party with the yellow banana on the table
results.name: Ethnic Eats goes to Melrose for Latin American food

venue.name: Roots and Wings Yoga and Healing ArtsCenter

results.description:
The theme for our Aug. 5 session is "Connecting to the Field of Spirit and Shifting Out of small-self Thinking".

Please join us for another evening of pure relaxed bliss; insight, inspiration, and upliftment!  And I make it really easy for you, too. I have some REALLY great meditations I'm excited to share with you. So mark your calendars to save the dates, RSVP YES, and we'll see you there!

Only 2 classes left this summer: August 5 and 19. In September, we will most likely return to the 1st and 3rd Friday evenings each month, starting Sept. 18. You do not have to commit to attending every class, however, the more you attend, the more you will benefit!   (Other meetups will begin again in the Fall, as well.)

To encourage and support your practice, if you pay for 4 classes, the fee will be only $60 (in-person, cash or check).   Or, you can pay for one class at a time for $20.  Just RSVP each time you want to attend. RSVP is recommended and appreciated, as well as showing up or changing your RSVP in a timely manner.

Are you aware of the many benefits of meditating, but can’t get yourself to do it, or it’s too difficult to do on your own?

Do you enjoy the collective energy and ease of guided group meditations?

Meditation can be one of the easiest and most effective means to living with greater harmony, happiness and well-being. It’s also an opportunity to peacefully transform your problems, your fears, and any pain and stress in your life into something more positive.

We also consider meditating one of the most direct and easiest ways to connect to your greater Spirit-Self and to build that relationship and ease with it; and to be in a vibration that allows all that you desire to easily flow to you. We think it's one of the most valuable practices you can have to effectively use the law of attraction, and to feel good (also important for manifesting good things)!

By participating in these guided meditations classes, you’ll experience how simple,delightful and easy it can be. You’ll learn and practice:

• Simple yet profound techniques you can easily do for yourself for any length of time that is comfortable for you.

• How to easily get into a meditative state to deeply relax and to create positive, pleasurable feelings, including inner peace, love, ease and joy; and how to bring that into your daily living.

Techniques to help you shift your perspective and experience of issues in your life causing you stress in some form, and to shift to Spirit perspective, instead.

• How to connect to your inner resources and your best self, to solution consciousness, and how to activate your body's natural healing response.

We have a different theme each class to help build and reinforce positive thinking patterns, beliefs and inner narratives that will support you in living with greater inner peace, love, ease and joy.

Each class consists of 2-3 guided meditations, with discussion and instruction in between to help you carry the positive feelings and lessons experienced into your day and life.

This is a perfect time to let go of stress and "busy-ness", and to fully let go and relax into bliss.  Come with whatever intentions suit you, and the evening is still sure to satisfy.  It always works out magically that way.

You're encouraged to bring a journal or notebook and pen to class.

“I'm leaving refreshed, optimistic, empowered, full of love, and excited about bringing more spirit into everything I do.  I’m sure that practicing the techniques I learned tonight will help me very much.  Thank you!!! "

"Great meditations!  I had a marvelous experience with each of them and a lot to take with me: powerful imagery, good feelings, and new techniques for connecting myself with the Universe. Loved the “love ripple”!”

Class leader (and meetup organizer): Ann Ide, M.A., certified master practitioner in Neuro-linguistic Programming and Hypnotherapy, and certified NLP Life Coach. Ann coaches people to move beyond their personal struggles, to new levels of harmony, happiness and success. With her expert questioning, inner exploration processes and personal change interventions, clients become able to more easily create the happiness they desire.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be on the first floor in the Wings Studio; (Note: extra parking available on Stafford St., by the Dairy Queen. Do not park at the DQ).
results.name: Guided Meditation Class for Experiencing Greater Inner Peace, Love, Ease and JOY
