results.description:
This Week's Ride: Apple Pi Ride


9:30 for 55 and 35 miles 

More details on the CRW Calendar: http://bit.ly/Iw67FE

Description:

The short ride goes through Concord, Acton, Littleton, Westford, and Carlisle. The long ride adds Stow and Harvard. The long ride passes an impressive array of apple orchards, while taking in a few hills.

This is the arrow to follow for the ride:

This is a re-occuring ride every Sunday beginning in April, with the organized and marked rides of CRW (Charles River Wheelmen). The picture above is from one of last years rides. Don't let the # of RSVPs here fool you, these rides are always well atended usually with over 25 riders of all abilities.

The distances and routes vary every week. We'll have "No Drop Rule" so you won't have to worry about getting lost or keeping up. Ride with us if you ride anywhere from 15 to 20 MPH.

Always bring two spare tubes, and your preferred hydration and nutrition. We don't typically stop for lunch but depending on the ride, there are sometimes options to stop for a bit. Before riding it's good practice to get your bike tuned. Remember to dress for the elements.

Also CRW organizes a Spring Century, a Summer Century called Climb to the Clouds, and a Fall Century. All of the Centuries have organized food and water stops. I'm hoping to get a group committed to building up to these Century rides.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for EH riding Jerseys
results.name: Weekly Sunday Bike Ride

results.description:
Have you ever wanted to make a piece of high-tech jewelry? Join us to learn how to 3D print your own jewelry. This 3 hour workshop will take you through designing and building your very own 3D printed bracelet, necklace, or key chain. You'll learn how to make a 3D model using 3D CAD, and how to use a 3D printer to make your designs. Space is limited, so register soon. 

Please bring your own machine if you have one, there are only 6 available from HATCH.
results.how_to_find_us: HATCH is located at the Arsenal Mall/Project at 485 Arsenal St. Park by the entrance that has a big green HATCH sign over the doors. You'll find us between Pearle Vision and Game Stop.
results.name: Intro to 3D Design and Printing

results.description:
Please join the first 2015 calorie neutral ice cream bike ride. We will meet at Lincoln-Sudbury Regional High School parking lot (enter on Lincoln Street and park toward the rear of the lot) and ride to Uhlman's Ice Cream in Westborough (http://uhlmansicecream.com/), which I have heard has very good ice cream (my VP swears by this place!). Total riding is 33 miles, so there are no calories for any ice cream eaten during this ride.

Important stuff: Helmets are mandatory and no ear buds or headphones please. You should have 1 - 2 filled water bottles and a spare tube that fits your tire. Lunch is optional (I don't know if there is anywhere along the way to buy something, but, frankly, isn't ice cream a complete meal???). Although this is a no rider left behind ride, it's important to keep a minimum of 11 - 13 mph average pace. I will have printed cue sheets available at the start of the ride.
results.name: Calorie Neutral Ice Cream Ride

results.description:
Date is advertised as Sunday, August 10th... but Sunday falls on the 9th... as date approaches, will confirm...

Boston's Chinatown comes alive with lion dances, martial arts, firecrackers, folk dances, and lots of vendors for the annual Chinese Moon Festival, also called the Mid-Autumn Festival.

The festival celebrates the legend of Chang'e, the immortal Lady of the Moon, and the overthrow of the Mongol rulers in 1368 when a rebel leader distributed mooncakes (which Mongols didn't eat) with messages hidden inside saying "Kill the Mongols." Mooncakes are round pastries filled with lotus seed paste.

Although this 3,000+ year old Chinese festival traditionally falls on the 15th day of the 8th Lunar month - in other words, late September / early October - Boston celebrates it in mid-August.
results.how_to_find_us: At the Gate
results.name: August Moon Festival - Chinatown

results.description:
It's no secret. Organic food is expensive. We do the best we can, but occasionally (or often) we succumb to buying conventional foods from the nearest grocery store. What if there was group of local friends who banded together to be able to enjoy top quality, organic food at reasonable prices?

For this Meetup, I'd like to get as many of us together as possible to gather information so we can plan the most useful and affordable co-op possible. What types of products do you use most often? What is the biggest part of your grocery bill? Maybe there is an item you have trouble finding the quality you want? Maybe you just can't keep spending your whole paycheck on dinner. Have access to the best products at the best prices.
Dry goods like grains, beans, nuts, seeds, coffee, teas, sweeteners
Body care products like soaps, shampoos, toothpaste, deodorants
As we grow we can incorporate perishables like locally grow vegetables and fruits (the biggest part of my food budget!)
results.how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
results.name: Lets Build an Organic Co-op!

http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-north/callahan-state-park.html

We would love to have you join us for this meetup, so you can get to know other trail dogs and their humans.

Please drop us a note and also join us on August 9!

Sincerely,
Don, Boston Trail Dogs.

results.description:
We will be working through Meyer text on the Dussack.  We will also look at how these techniques apply to  One-handed or arming sword.

We are going to interpret Joachim Meyer’s Dussak.  The translation we will use is in

The Art of Combat: A German Martial Arts Treatise of 1570 (Hardcover)

http://www.amazon.com/gp/offer-listing/1848327781/ref=sr_1_5_twi_2_har_olp?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1434813702&sr=1-5&keywords=meyer

with additional material from Meyer’s 1560 work

https://sites.google.com/site/jochimmeyer1560/home/Meyer_1560_english_Maurer_2012.pdf?attredirects=0&d=1

From Jakob Sutor’s “New Illustrated Fechtbuch” of 1612

https://docs.google.com/file/d/0Bxqzt-jcOCFsT19Xa1Q2QXltWm8/edit

Finally some from

Cod.Guelf.83.4 Aug.8º


http://www.thearma.org/Manuals/Codex-Guelf-83.4-Aug-8f-translation.pdf
results.name: Dussack, One-handed sword, Interpreting Meyer Dussack

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
